really nice hike! Rocky and lots of roots which make it interesting. it was easy to follow an well marked. Some very beautiful views would be great for a picnic. Need good hiking or running shoes if you want to climb up on some of the boulders. In and out of the forest with some sunny spots along the way. Good for a morning or afternoon activity as it's not too long.

Excellent trail. Well marked and relatively intuitive for the most part. Lots of inclines and descents throughout the loop with varying terrain. Beautiful views. Took about 2-2.5 hours for the pot lake loop at a brisk pace.

A great hike for an autumn day. The leaves are turning and the scenery is beautiful.  
The tree roots and rocks in the trail can be a bit of a challenge. It can be hard on the knees. 
The scenery is worth the hike!
beautiful trail! Nice way to spend 2-3 hrs. we took a snack and had a picnic at one of the many nice openings where we could see the lake.

kids 7 and 5 were able to do it. lots of climbing around rocks which the kids loved, but can be hard on the knees. trail was fairly obvious, well beaten path and enough other hikers around to feel sure of where you are.
lots of roots and rocks on the trail. It was dry when I hiked but you can see a few spots where it is usually muddy.
Great day for a hike. At the fork take the right it is more difficult but makes the return easier. Due to the weather this summer the trail is quite dry.
Nicely maintained moderate use. Very rocky and roots tail surface. Well marked. No bugs when we hiked 11 to 2 pm aug 14

This was a beautiful hike but was by far one of the more challenging ones I have completed, I would rate it closer to hard than moderate. The trail is moderate in that it is fairly easy to navigate and the slightly uneven ground to walk over branches and rocks most of the hike, however the length pushed it out of a moderate rating and into a hard for me, and there were points that could have used better marking too so you do have to be fairly comfortable with navigation. Despite it being a loop we somehow came out of the same place we went in which I assume is due to lacking markers towards the end of the trail, I ending up leading my self through the woods to the point I entered at rather than closing the loop.
Loved this hike. Excellent variety in terrain with a nice challenge in elevation.

Great trail for running. Great elevation change and a variety of scenery. Bugs can be pretty dense so bring some bug spray!  Trail is easy to follow so don't worry about using your phone or GPS to guide you. Trail is marked and signs are at interesections detailing which way to go. Love this one.
great trail with some mildly challenging rocks and hills.

I’ve done this three times in the last six weeks. It’s a great trail. Lots of big rocks and tree roots. For a well used trail I hardly encounter anyone on it. Was there after supper tonight and saw two people.
Great hike. Lots of climbing and easy to navigate trails. Some markers along the way but the foot paths are pretty easy to spot to keep you on track. Definitely bring bug spray!
Very nice walk!!
Great spot for all levels of hikers!
Nice hike. Some steep sections to provide a workout. Lots of exposed tree roots as this is the first and most used loop. Not crazy busy this time of year.
beautiful day on the trail today. did it in 1h40 and was walking with a fast pace. most scenic views are to the right on the first half of the trail. will definitely be back

was a beautiful day for a hike. parking lot to parking lot took me one hour forty minutes. I walk fairly quick and don't stop often for pictures unless something catches my eye. most of the scenic part of the trail is on the right side when you get to the fork. will definitely be back again !
Nice 2 hour and 15 minute hike but quite frequent encounters on this loop.
ran the pot lake loop. very beautiful and the trails are extremely well marked. also very close to the city if you're looking to get away quickly
This was only my second hike ever, parts were challenging, but overall great trail and view at the top. Can’t wait to try the rest of the loops!
Best done in May before bugs and people come out! Or in the Fall maybe.

Beautiful trail and views. We picked a very hot and humid day to hike here and will choose a cooler day next time. Luckily, we had lots of water with us and we took our time! Highly recommend this trail.
Really enjoyed this trail. Lots of great views. Well marked and easy to follow. Kids loved that there were lots of boulders to climb. Will be coming back to hike some of the other Bluff Trail loops.

I run this trail 1-2 times a year. A great workout and pushes me to my limits. If you are trail-running, plan at least an hour+ for this run and bring lots of water. If you are hiking, plan at least 3+ hours. everywhere along the course you will find great views.
Great hike. Really will do it again some day. I encourage everyone around to go and do it.
Great hike very beautiful with lots of places to stop and enjoy the view. As often said lots of roots and some climbs but all in all doable.
Great little trail.  Given my experience I would rate it as moderate. A lot of rocks and roots to walk through and a few good climbs.
Beautiful! Great moderate hike.
Hard
Great terrain. Good sized loop for an afternoon hike.
Great trail, great work-out!  Well marked and very clean.
Good trail and not super well marked which is fun, kind of close to the highway so you can hear the cars pretty much into the loop. only downside though
Beautiful trail! Definitely more challenging than expected. My only complaint is lack of trail marking can make it easy to get lost and end up on one of the longer loops!
this was a surprise for me and my girlfriend who enjoy challenging trails. I recommend this hike
Absolutely beautiful hiking trails, dog friendly on leash. Absolutely breathe taking views. Multiple trails within the one trail. Difficult at times but worth every minute.
Of all the 4 loops of the Bluff Wilderness, the Pot Lake Loop provides the best cardio workout.  Good signage to help you navigate from each trail loop and amazing views.
Great trail, lots of fun technical hills, with great views
Awesome views! Muddy but no bugs and worth every step!

Did the whole thing in one day… listening to music and using the app to track drained my battery way too quick, hence the gap in the trail map. Official time in 08:08 and time out 20:17… was shooting for 10 hours but still feel great about finishing it in one day.  Trail was pretty visible.  Got lost 1-2 times but I had the app to put me back on track… very wet and mucky in lots of spots.  Can’t wait to try it again next year for a better time.
The trail is breathtaking, in more ways then one.

Completed the full loop counterclockwise with my mom and my dog. Note that the full loop is 51km and not 44.9km.

Day 1 (Red rocks - Seal Cove, 20km)
This is the longest day in kms, however the terrain is relatively flat for the most part. Not a very scenic day as most is spent in the woods. Camping at Seal Cove was great, we spent the night on the beach watching the sunset and my dog swimming. We had campsite #4 and it was good, the picnic table was nice to have.

Day 2 (Seal Cove - Refugee Cove, 18km) 
This is the most scenic day with lots of viewpoints. Very muddy though which definitely slows you down. The campsites at Refugee are really nice. We had #3 which also had a picnic table. It's a little walk getting to the beach though, which we were too tired to go so just stayed at the campsite.

Day 3 (Refugee Cove - Red Rocks, 13km)
Not as many kms but definitely more challenging with a big ascent right after leaving the campsite and then another big one going up an ATV trail. We also took the wooded trail at the end since we weren't sure about the tides, which gives you an extra 2km compared to taking the beach.

Mosquitos were REALLY bad when we went (Aug 22 - 24). Lots of water to filter and the trail is well marked. Overall great trail and could definitely see myself making it a yearly hike! :)
Awesome hike, 9/10 difficulty, beautiful views the whole way along the coast. Lots of water to drink the entire time too

Tough but stunning hike! We only did a portion of the park and climbed almost 2,000m in elevation. Loved it! So much so I am planning to do the 3 night/4 day total trail!! 
Finished with a 3k run along the shore in West Advocate!!

Stumbled on the trail ramdomly coming off of the beach. Cool views of the orange sand beach but over all hard trail. We didn't start at km 1 and had a hard time finding our way. There were no indications anywhere except for km's. So we had no idea how many km's all together. It was also quite a long hike before having an option to get out of the forest. Overall hard but I think would have appreciated it more if we knew what was coming and were more prepared.

An awesome hike forsure! We hiked counter clockwise, the trail was quite muddy between little bald rock and eatonville but the views make up for that! The two huge hills everyone talks about are wheeler trails so going up isn’t to bad, it’s just a long haul to the top. Tons of water to fill up which is great and the campsites are pretty good! Some have actual picnic tables others just have boards and stumps to make a makeshift table. Also no fires are supposed to be allowed on the backcountry campsites, so that was a bummer, but still an amazing hike, would recommend!

Very well-marked trail, with some beautiful views, lots of wildlife, and terrain variation. As some other reviewers have mentioned, there were some very boggy spots partway through, but nothing that couldn't be handled. 

Regarding wildlife, we saw eagles, rabbits, deer, and frogs, and a number of jays. 

We hiked the trail in 4 days, 3 nights. There is lots of beach access along many parts of the trail. 

Highly recommended for those interested in a multi-day hike. Remember that the tides in the area are dramatic and move quickly- keep an eye on your stuff if you have it on the beaches, and keep it above the tide line!

Tough trail for sure, but an amazing experience. Did the loop counter clockwise in 4 days, three nights — it was nice to get the wooded area done on the first day, and then have the coast for the rest of the time. Plus counting down the kms was so motivating for me!
Some big hills up and down, and lots of muddy portions of the trail between Seal Cove and Refugee Cove. Saw lots of wildlife, and lots of friendly hikers and dogs.
Can’t wait to do it again!

Did the trail in 2 days, 1 night. Hiked from Red Rocks to Keyhole Brook (26.8km) then to Eatonville to complete 36.5km (in lieu of returning along the 15km inland part). If we had booked earlier we would have stayed in Big Bald Rock instead only because it’s a shorter distance, but no sites were available. Would recommend completing the trail clockwise since the hardest section is to Refugee Cove followed by the climb to get out of the cove. Occasionally felt blisters forming but with a little moleskin was able to stop them in their tracks. It would be a smart idea to bring hiking poles - about 50% of the people we saw didn’t have poles and I was genuinely concerned for their safety. The trail is very steep and muddy in sections and the poles were everything in those moments. Plenty of streams with clear water so finding water was never an issue. Wore hikers on day 1 and trail runners on day 2 and it felt great to have dry shoes. Will definitely do this trail again, perhaps over three days or book earlier so we can travel less on day 1. Do your research before going!!

This is a hidden gem. The hiking was tough but the views were the pay off. There wasn’t a section of the whole loop that I would have wanted to miss. Three of us did this trail in three nights and four days. Glad I trained a little!

Amazing but brutal trail. Hiked red rocks to little bald rock on day 1. Then to Eatonville on day 2 and finally back to red rocks on day 3. Lots of blister and sore legs by the end. Would definitely do it again just gave me a year to recover.

Wet in spots and getting wide as folks avoid the mud. Need some volunteer trail crew to lay some logs and work on drainage.
Well signed trail with great views of the bay of fundy (or sometimes just fog). 
Geologically interesting, lots of wildlife. 
One of very few multi day hikes with campsites in all of NS.
Definitely came as advertised!!

Completed the full coastal loop with my partner and 10 year old daughter this past week. Absolutely stunning views and by far the most challenging hike any of us have ever completed. We cried and we laughed, lots of great memories!
Wonderful long weekend trip. I’ve done this trail both dry and wet, and in both directions. The trail is a bit rough in the rain but manageable. I would highly recommend!

Did this 51km loop clockwise in two nights, three full days of hiking with a friend and our two dogs. We started at the visitor center and stayed at Refugee Cove on night 1 and Seal Cove for night 2. Highly recommend both sites as the camp sites are right next to beautiful beaches. Not all sites have beach access so these two are a must! Difficult pace for only two nights especially if you want some down time but very enjoyable of you're up to the task :)

I ended up driving from New Brunswick Friday afternoon after work, and hiking into the dark. I had not planned my clothing well and was too cold to sleep in hammock so my dog and I ended up hiking the loop through the night. We were able to hear the ocean. But missed out on the views!! By daylight we were finishing up, signed out when lodge opened and slept in car for a few hours before driving home. Need to redo this. But it was a beautiful hike from the little bit we saw. It is longer then the site had said as well. We were happy to see the end when it finally came.

Amazing trail! But it is 51.4 km and NOT 44.9 as All Trails claims. First day is 12 km to Refugee Cove is a tough and technical section with 3 big climbs and descents - including one extremely steep descent - and ending in Refugee Cove. We spent our second night 14 km later at Keystone Brook which was a great site. We would have preferred to get to Seal Cove but because of a late start and ran out of daylight at 5pm and wanted to be able to see the stunning coastline. Day 3 was therefore 25 km back to the parking lot. It was a great stroll through the woods with a big ascent and decent towards the end. The trail was well marked. I wish they had names for all of the lookouts. Absolutely stunning coastline.

Trail Run - 50km Full Loop: 

Started the route on the overland section to Eatonville. The trail was in good condition for running and I covered the first 18km in about 2.5 hours. The west coast section was quite a bit slower due to a combination of steep declines and inclines, lots of tricky tree roots, and skirting frequent wet sections but also beach visits, photo ops, snack breaks, view points, etc. It is absolutely beautiful on the west coast section. I was about 4.5 hours on this section. As soon as I turned the corner at the cape the trail running conditions improved and I was able to maintain a decent pace except for the steep climbs out of Refugee Cove and Mill Creek. 

Total time for the full loop 9hrs 10min. 

Water: there were lots of places to get water along the route. I drank directly from streams the whole way.

Really great time! I did this around the middle of July and there wasn’t one mosquito or black fly! 

Red rocks-Refugee Cove
Refugee Cove-Seal Cove
Seal Cove-Eatonville

Refugee was my favourite place. Tide was out so I explored to the right of the beach and took in all of the wonderful cliffs and rocks. Stayed at site one at both camp sites and those were both good spots. Lots of places for water which is lovely. I’d consider doing this in 3 nights, 4 days next time to thoroughly enjoy it.
Longest day for me, the part missing on my recording...forgot on pause!!   People say its the boring part of the loop, mostly in the wood.  But i really enjoy it, peaceful in the wood :)

This is a great trail with amazing views!!  I definitely recommend this trail, and will do it again next year.  As the distances aren't too long between campsites and the hills aren't too bad, this trail is suited to new and seasoned backpackers.  There are plenty of water sources along the entire trail.

Day 1: Visitor center to Refugee Cove - 3h45m.  Took a short break at mill brook.  This section of the trail was well maintained with a few hills.  There are a handful of points that allow you to see the coast.  Stayed in RC1.  Sites 1 and 2 looked nice.  I didn't see the other sites.  Just past site 2 on the right there is a little opening with a great tree for a PCT bear hang. A short walk from campsite to beach with cook kit, made for a nice supper.

Day 2: Refugee Cove to Eatonville - 8h15m. the morning was foggy with no views, but it cleared up by lunch. This section was definitely the most scenic.  There are so many great spots for photos and take in the views.  Terrain was very rooty, but not much for hills.  A few short ups and downs.  Around km marker 25, got stung in the back of the head.  Didn't see or hear any nest until it was too late.  Lunch at Big Bald, and a couple breaks.  Arrived at Seal cove(original booking) at 3:30pm and wanted to push on.  Called and change my res to Eatonville.  Arrived at Eatonville at 5pm.  I had site 1 which is a great site.  Site 2 right beside is great also.  Both are right next to a good section of the brook.  Had difficulty finding a good tree for bear hang, but as I was the only one in the entire Eatonville campground, there was a great tree in site 2 to use.

Day 3: Eatonville to visitor center - 3h15m. It was very misty and wet, so I was motivated to get off the trail before the rain (supposed to hit afternoon).  The first and last parts of this section have a couple hills, but the middle is very flat (along brooks), so you can make some good time.  Although this section has no coastal views, it is quite pretty in spots.  If this was a dry day, I imagine I would have found myself stopping to look at the scenery.

The squirrels here really don’t mess about!! Hang all of your food properly as soon as you get to camp, they won’t hesitate to chew through anything your food is in. 

Other than that this trail is absolutely amazing!! We did 3 nights in total, doing it in reverse. 
Parking - Seal Cove - 6.5 hrs
Seal Cove - Big Bald Rock - 4.5hrs
Big Bald Rock - Refugee Cove - 4.5 hrs
Refugee Cove - Parking - 3 hr 15

We were really happy to get the 20k out of the way. Took lots of long breaks for views and really enjoyed the hikes on days 2 and 3. We were all warmed up to get the last day done quite quickly. All the campsites were really nice and the views here are just spectacular!! 

Would love to do this again, 4 days was perfect! Bringing poles next time though!

Fantastic hike! The trail is well-marked and maintained, as are the facilities. They clean the "pit privies" every 2 days. This was my first solo multi-day hike, and it was a really great one for it. I will definitely do this one again!

I hiked in a counter-clockwise direction staying at Seal Cove, Big Bald Rock, and finally Refugee Cove. I wanted to get the long 20 km day through mostly forests over with first, although that left the most difficult day for the end. One thing I really liked about doing it this way was that you hike through forests all day, and then finally getting to the coast and seeing those amazing views just makes it that much more breath-taking.

BEWARE OF SQUIRRELS. When I got to Big Bald Rock campsite, I dropped my pack and went to check out the beach. I made sure everything was closed up so rodents/squirrels/etc didn't get in. When I got back, a squirrel had chewed a hole in my pack. That night, the squirrels chewed a hole in my sealine bag which I had HUNG UP to deter wildlife from getting my food. I am very grateful to the other campers who saved my food from being totally ravaged by the squirrels. Hang your food, hang it well, and don't leave any food or food bags unattended even for a moment.

well maintained trail. did it in 3 days 2 nights. the campsite at little bald rock was nice and worth the extra kms. we got our campsite stolen at eatonville wich was a little annoying but luckily 2 other hiker shared a campsite and gave us one. overall excellent trail, lots of ups and down and lots of viewpoints. i highly recommend amd will do it again this year.

Another year, another fun trip! That last part from Seal Cove to Eatonville is so tough… I always miss and get high Tide. I debate going counter clockwise next year, but then I’ll miss the grand finale of the three sisters view… Though it would be cool doing the Eatonville day trails and getting more glimpses… The only camp I wouldn’t recommend is probably keyhole Brook… Every other site has its own special piece of the puzzle… I love doing this in super hot conditions. I was so grateful it didn’t rain… I did it in four days and three nights so I could really take it in… But in the future I might add another night on… Because I was in paradise being there.
It’s definitely no walk in the park...haha. What an amazing trail. I’ll post more shortly
Great hike from Eatonville Rd near km#36 into Sealy Cove -km#30.5... nice ocean breeze... just shy 12km in/out.
Great walk on the beach to get to the actual trail and the views on the trail are amazing.
I hated walking over the beach rocks  but this trail was worth it!
lovely trail!!! amazing views. easy going.

Not a walk in the park!

opening and closing on the beach, with your choice of sand or lose rock. The trail proper has excellent views over minor elevation change. several easy over/easy under tree falls.  Corduroy logs in serious need of some TLC, but nothing impassable with some willingness to get muddy.
A little rocky in parts but lovely seashore!
Tons of fun! have done this trail twice, last year and this! Caught the sunset at Gaff Point through the fog and was still beautiful. Next trip we will hunt for thw hidden beach

Beautiful, and well maintained!!! There's one part during the loop that gets you pretty close to a cliff, so beware if you have a fear of heights. It made my stomach turn! But otherwise loved it, and got to see some wildlife too
beautiful trail!
Took the trail less travelled along the right side of the cliff and it was lovely! Lead us to a secret beach??!! Incredible views of the fog lifting as we came back along the left
great trail. well maintained, with beautiful views
Very nice. Clean. Cool logs to walk on in places. Beautiful views. When we got to the Loop we went around anti-clockwise and would recommend.￼
Beautiful trail, great views! Busy on a beautiful summer day.
Excellent
Beautiful trail, easy terrain.
Wonderful
Beautiful! Takes about an hour and 40 minutes at a good pace.
The beach part took a while because the trail is over a lot of rocks. But once you get past the beach the rest of the trail is good!
Beautiful trail. Very well maintained and the views are well worthy of the 5 km hike
Beauty!  Of the 4.1 miles, 3.9 was breathtaking.
Beautiful beach and trial! Highly recommend.
One of my favorite trails in NS! The scenery was amazing.
Cool walk in but a warmer walk out. Trail is getting more rugged each year.
Beautiful hike, easy trail, family friendly. Lucked out with low tide and did not have to deal with beach cobble. Fantastic ocean views the entire trail.
ROCKS ROCKS ROCKS oh u want to on a trail, prepare for an unsteady walk on q rocky Beach (1,5km) before u even get to the trail. pack an extra pair of ankles
Wonderful hike! Not hard and stunning. very well cared for.
Awesome hike. Beautiful views everywhere you look.
Incomparable ocean scenery, but the beach there is rocky, and the logs on the trail offer a solid but bumpy path. Wear good shoes, and try to visit at low tide.
Great trail, pretty easy walk other than the cobbles from the beach. Well marked! Bring some good waterproof sneakers as it’s quite mucky after rain.
Trail is in good shape and 98% ice free. Great views. Not a lot of traffic.

Went on this trail with three of my best friends. We drove down from Hali in my friends sexy white charger. There is levels to Gaff Point, it’s like multiple experiences on the same trail. It’s the perfect length and honestly a top 3 trail for me.

this one was really hard on old girl hips. lots of roots and rock in the loop. walking along the beach section even in low tide was challenging.  sunny day and beautiful views, saw a really big bunny and two eagles. be careful close to the cliffs especially if you take a dog. ice was gone and mud was starting to thaw. thanks to the folks who maintain the trail with addition of logs and wooden bridges.
Trail starts out on the beach so it’s a bit rocky, definitely need good ankle support! Views are beautiful

The snow on the trail through the Nature Conservancy land is packed down nicely with only a couple patches of ice on the way up the hill. Lovely spot, with a seal hanging out in the beach on the way back to the parking lot.
Trail was nice and packed down which made it easy to follow

Great well marked trail but one spot at the halfway point had me searching for the yellow markers. Definitely want a good pair of hiking boots with ankle support as you are walking on beach rocks, shale and logs in various places. Lovely look off points in places. Definitely muddy and wet along many spots. The trail says 6.5km but my Fitbit tracker said 7.5km from the parking lot. On the return, took the trail on the hill next to the beach but owners ask you only do so when no horses in the field. Some people had their dogs but do caution that the shale along the ocean may be rough on their paws. Enjoy!
Easy hike, trail is a little slick. I’ve done it before In the summer and the trail can be muddy.
Beautiful trail, proper hiking footwear is needed. high cliffs and beautiful ocean views; I recommend this trail pack a lunch and bring your camera.
Definitely not an "easy" trail. Need good, solid hiking boots as you walk along pebbles at first and then later slippery rock. Well marked. Beautiful views!
Beautiful hike! I’ve done this one a few times, never gets old.
Well kept trail with stunning scenery. As others have pointed out, there is a variety of terrain so wear proper footwear. Overall an easy hike and well worth doing.

Easy trekking, well marked with yellow paint markers & beautiful views. Loved the varied types of pathways along the trail: stone, split logs, corduroy logs..nice mix up. It was chilly starting out but was a great day to be hiking today!
Great trail, beautiful scenery.
Excellent! Well marked and gorgeous views. Third time back and still love it!
If you haven't done this trail, well, you should... great trail with awesome views and moderate difficulty... Sunset is stunning if you can time your hike well.

The trail itself was only challenging at the beginning- as in walking over the beach rocks. I used the private property hill on the way back because I found it so atrocious. 
The trail is for the most part clearly marked with yellow indicators so you don’t get lost. Whether it be on trees or rocks by the sea side just follow them. 
The path is well maintained and an easy adventure walk. The scenery is absolutely stunning. The trail took me 7.5 KM and 2 hours as I dilly dallied a bit to take photos and footage on my camera. 
I didn’t have any problems with ticks.
Beautiful evening for the hike. 70 mins to complete.
The rocks at the beginning were not too easy to negotiate but the rest of the trail was great!

So, the first thing you need to know is that google maps sends you to the wrong place. No worries, the local residents have erected some signs to prevent you from going down the wrong road. Just keep going past the last road that google wants you to turn on and, instead, turn on Hirtle Beach Rd. There is a large parking lot there and it’s fairly obvious you’ve arrived.

The parking lot was packed but not full when we arrived in a Saturday at 11:00 AM. By the time we left at 1:30 PM, people were parking up and down the road

The only crappy part was walk the first/last part of walking across the rocks at the beginning/end along Hirtle beach. It’s a rock painters dream, however. Do yourself a favour and take the uphill walk along the cliff to save yourself some walking on the rocks. It’s private property but the owners only ask you to stay away if the horses are in the field. 

It took about 25 minutes to get to the trail proper. It eventually is a loop. There is an earlier point that looks like it might be the loop but watch for the yellow markers. They lead you to the left. At the actual split, you can go either left or right. Left is a bit more challenging. 

Trail is easy to moderate. The kids and dogs can do it but not strollers. The Hirtle Beach portion is not for weak ankles or flip flops. 

Took is an hour and 5 minutes to reach Gaff Point in the middle. Nice inukshuks there and a few spots to stop for snack/break. Some really nice coastal views along the way. Trail is very mixed between wide forest path and walking along slate rocks. It is well marked with yellow paint. Trail conditions are great.
Great trail, pretty well marked and we found the secret beach. It starts on a beach and there’s all kinds of terrain but ultimately it’s a pretty easy, slightly moderate spot. Great views!
Amazing trail! Moderate difficulty. Worth the view!
A must do. Great scenery of the ocean and interesting rock formations
Terrain changed from sand to beach rock, to roots and granite rock.  West stable shoes.  Beautiful view.  There is a hidden beach but it was busy so not that secret and that was a cooler week day
Very nice trail but very difficult to find due to incorrect directions on Google Maps.
Beauty!!
beautiful trail with a great beach. bring your swimsuit for some water fun after this hike. the waves are bomb.

A beautiful hike. Going at low tide is best so you can walk on the sandy beach. Otherwise you'll have to walk on the beach stones which is a bit awkward. There are some gorgeous views from the cliffs.
Love this coastal trail! Make sure to repel down to the sandy beach below. Spectacular views of the ocean and islands.
2 days in a row! Spectacular hike
Check my instagram for 12 min video. Awesome spot. Loved the walk and sights do not disappoint! Have proper footwear. No flipflops. @drscottmaclean #gaffpointtrail

Great trail. It was a foggy day but still a great trail. Well maintained and easy to follow. Crossing a Stoney beach to start and end trail was the roughest ground. It was busy we met about 6 groups along the trail.
Great and not to busy when I arrived at 10am. That changed when i returned to my car though.
Beautiful trail. You have to walk on the beach for about 20 mins to get there which was nice as well. Few spots have downed trees on the trail but nothing too onerous to cross.

rocky along the water but fine once you hit the trail. honestly I've done a lot of hiking and this has been the best hike to date! Comparable to Taylor Head but I would say I enjoyed this more..  we even got to dip in the very cold and refreshing ocean afterward. highly recommend checking this one out!!!
Loved this trail! A few trees down across the trail after storms this year. Not too hard to crawl around them though!

My definition of the perfect hike.  The trail is well marked and offers fantastic views throughout.  Loved the different terrain at various parts of the trail - from well-worn dirt paths, smooth rounded rocks, wooden planks, flat top stones, and more.  The trail is well maintained.

Awesome trail. Hiked along the beach until we got to the trail head just to the right. Extremely well marked once you’re on the trail. We kept to the left along the loop where we hiked through an area of sharp-ish rocks with a gorgeous ocean view. The point is a great place to stop and have a quick bite to eat. The way back was a bit wet with a couple of tree stumps to climb over but very well maintained. There were zero bugs but it was also only 14 degrees when we did the hike. Can’t wait to go back!

I love this trail. The only downfall at all is that the first and last is a very rocky 1 km each way that can be hard on the ankles but the rest is great and probably one of the best hikes on the south shore.
Trail is pretty well kept. Absolutely gorgeous views but a lot of the time you’re watching what your stepping on (on a lot of rocks). Very busy, thin trails. Great for a family walk.
Has to be one of the best trials I’ve explored so far. The trail was easily hiked and the views at every turn were breathtaking. Definitely recommend this trial. Will be back again.
Great trail, beautiful sites

One of my favourite hikes this year. We went a few days after Hurricane Dorian, so there were several downed trees across parts of the trail. That made some parts tricky, but still passable. The views are spectacular and worth climbing over some trees! We did it with our two dogs, they did find walking on the beach through the pebbles a bit difficult.

Wonderful views dry trail end of August, wear supportive comfortable shoes for the beach rocks and navigating tree roots, did the whole route in under 2 hrs taking time to stop for several photos along the point, if you choose to do only half the loop start on the left side for views if you don't mind some spots beach rock, someone painted yellow markers here n there for trail, can appreciate the logs in the marshy area that is needed during rains but personally didn't favour them on this dry day, the cliffs and mosses were beautiful and I would walk it again.
Great hike, lot of nice views. The trail is well maintained, Recommend going out at low Tide.
Trail was a great quick hike. From start to finish took me 1 hour 20 minutes with no stops in between. This trail is not strenuous but you definitely have to be sure footed on the beach rocks.

Went on 03/08/2019. Started trail at noon, from Hirtle's Beach parking lot. The whole trail took us about 2 hours, with numerous stops and a swim at Hirtle's beach at the end. Walk down the beach for a couple kms to get to the actual trailhead. There's a few options to this: Walk on the sand, then up the rocks, or cut onto the farmer's private property and follow the foot trail up and back down the hill. We decided to walk along the beach. The rocks aren't that difficult, but witnessed some people struggling with their footing. An information board with a trail map indicates the started of the provincially maintained trail. You walk in abit and theres a three-pronged junction. Two of those have yellow spray paint indicating the trail to follow (That is used as the trail marker). This is the start of a loop. We took the right-most trail, hiking the trail clockwise. It is easy hiking through the forest, with numerous viewpoints of the ocean. The third path, the furthermost left trail, is an unmaintained foot path that'll lead you to the so-called "secret beach". This trail weaves along the cliff edge, and you may think that you're lost, but follow it to the end. Once arriving at the end, theres an overlook of the beach down below. Access it via the rope. Could be slippery if if was a wet day, so use your better judgement. Same can be said for swimming at that beach.  
I would say the hike is a 3.5/5. Not that challenging, but on a nice day its a good afternoon hike. Not strenuous in the slightest.

I went at 8am on a Friday morning and there were 3 people at the beach and no one else on the trail. The volunteers do a great job of maintaining the trail though I felt a few yellow blazes could have been added. Gorgeous scenery though. Take tick spray and wear solid boots.
What an awesome hike. This trail is worth every minute of driving to get to. Don’t miss the unmarked trail to the hidden secret.

Was a trail with beautiful views by the cliffs and on the beach.  Watch out for ticks and make sure you bring bug repellant. Trail was a little muddy in some areas but there were logs put down to step on.
Muddy sections need some upkeep but this is a favourite I have returned to for 14 years. I don’t have a dog but if you do look out for sharp shale sections on coastline portion of the trail.

went with a group from the Hike NS Summit.  we started out in light rain which made the stretch across Hirtle Beach cobble a bit more tricky than the return when it was dry.  The spring rains and steady use of this trail made it quite muddy when you reach the wooded sections of the trail.  Having said that, my feet stayed dry and there were no big problems.  I believe this will be a great hike on a sunny day as the coastal sections are dramatic.  I did find the cobble a bit annoying and tricky to walk on.  Poles were handy getting around the mud puddles.  This trail is protected by the NS Nature Trust and the Nature Conservancy of Canada and the Kingsburg Trails Assoc?
Did the hike today. the trail is very wet and muddy ( it rained for like a week) there is alot of roots, so watch your step. the views are still awesome ❤
love this trail!!! haven't found the secret beach yet, maybe next time.I am going back with in the next 2 weeks.
great trail! I would rate it moderate for the uneven terrain  and some muddy bits
A great day with family.  We really enjoyed the trail as well as watching the giant waves coming to shore as we walked along the ocean.

Definitely recommend this hike! It was suggested to us while we were visiting the area from Ontario in February. As many others said, the first stretch is along a very rocky beach but when you get to the trail it is well marked and well maintained. Beautiful views of the cliffs and water. We had some icy spots so I imagine other times of the year it could be quite muddy. We took about 2 hours from the parking lot and back with stops for pictures and views.
Great trail with beautiful Oceanside views. The first km or so was crazy rocky, so be sure to have boots with good ankle support. Would definitely hike this trail again.

A very rewarding hike with excellent ocean views. The first part of the trail crosses an eternity of lose beach rocks on the upper side of the beach. You should wear hiking shoes with ankle support - good place to roll an ankle. If you go in sneakers just be cautious. The trail itself is a loop with over half of it having ocean views. Good for on-leash dogs, however people like to break the rules which is rather annoying... parts of the wooded section of the trail can be extremely muddy but there are stones and boards to walk on to cross. There are also secrets to this trail. Find for yourself. 
This is an area known for high levels of ticks so always practice good after-hike inspections of yourself and your pets. A good dose of the (pet-friendly) Atlantick spray before hiking this area would be recommended. Overall, this is a hike I go back and do every few years as it’s interesting enough to do more than once.

Great short hike with rewarding elevation changes, ocean views, a magical forest, and a few secret paths that you should explore. it is not EASY.. the trail requires rugged shoes, is very uneven in places, and the stones on the beach can be very hard to walk along, watch your step.
Rocky beach, gorgeous cliff views, alternating terrain, inuksuks, mossy forests, a perfect day hike.
Great hike, with amazing views for relatively little effort.  Cobble beach to start, check tides.  Follow loop clockwise for best impact.  Build an inuksuk, swim at a secluded beach.

this trail begins at a lovely beach with good parking and bathrooms! the water is great for swimming and surfing! 

walking close to the water on softer sand is very comfortable and pleasent! when the shore turns rocky, head to high ground where there is a beaten path. otherwise the round unstable rocks make for a difficult walk for sure!
the terrain has many changes which really make this hike fun and far from boring! great views, places to sit on ground to rest/lunch, explore off trail along shore, break shale to collect Fool's Gold, swimming holes. there is a place to jump about 30' down into a good pool! but it's also a good place to slip off the edge as you are running for the jump, and break your back on the rocks below! this is also a dangerous spot on the hike for kids who struggle with being aware of their surroundings!
if you take your time to enjoy all this little gem has to offer, it is definitely an easy hike for all. any hike can be made difficult if you rush !! 
:)
amazing views. the walk to the trail head along the beach on the Sea stones is not fun, but the elevated views from the point are gorgeous.

Great trail. The first part along the beach is not the best way to start the trail, as it is quite long and not that beautiful... but lots of different paths and views are amazing ! Also not a lot of people so you get time to enjoy the trail on your own !
Beautiful trail. Easily accessible for the whole family. The first portion (the beach) is not representative of all the nice things you can see along the way.
Very nice trail with lots of different terrain and great views, it is quite annoying to get to the trail over the lose pebble beach but doesn’t take too long.

I did this trail 15 years ago with friends and everything I loved and hated about it then still applies.

Wear very supportive footware. This trail has many different types of terrain and having proper footware is a must.

Try and arrive so that you can use the beach to walk on instead of the ankle rolling pebbles. Check the tide times.

The views are spectacular. The ocean puts on a show at every turn.

Just make sure to leave lots of time, bring lots of water and proper food to sustain you and proper footware!
Great day on the trail. Enjoyed with young kids and grandparents. Good for all. Beautiful view and a great place to picnic or enjoy a day at the beach at the end.
Beautiful.
One of my favorite!
Lots of variety for a short hike,  should probably aim for around low tide for the beach bit.
This hike starts out on the beach, then meets up with a very well maintained trail! It was foggy when I hiked it, but still a very nice hike.
A Beautiful Coastal Trail with a mix of white sand beach, cobblestone shoreline, rocky cliff coastline, mossy meadows and evergreen forests.
Beautiful spot, lots of beautiful look out points and not a difficult trail.
Beautiful and well worth any trip. Park in the Hirtle Beach car park and run the coast along to Gaff Point. Worth any visit. Well conditioned trail
Nice walk with beautiful views!
Nice enough, particularly at the end. Recommend doing the loop as mapped.
Beautiful lookouts of the coast and Ingonish island. Fairly east hike well maintained trail even on a wet day. If you want to do one coastal hike in the park middle head is fantastic
We came around 5am to see the sunrise, however, unfortunately it was a foggy and grey day. Nonetheless, it is a beautiful trail along the peninsula. Proper moderate hike.
Nice view at the end. Very windy. Trail goes up and down.

Did this trail on a hot 30C sunny day with very little ocean breeze.  There are a LOT of ups and downs and rocks and roots to navigate the whole way. Views are beautiful at the end. Bring lots of water on a hot day. Well placed benches along the way. We were there third week of August and there were lots of wild raspberries to pick.
Loved this trail!!! Roots, hills and views!!! Great hike!
Super fun hike and amazing views.
nice view of the gulf, trail fairly easy
Amazing trail, one of the best in the area. We brought our 5 years old daughter and she was able to walk it completely. The best views
Nice little hike with my honey.

What a spectacular view!  The trail wasn’t difficult, but certainly not easy. There are many places to rest and a lot of up and down hills. Some terrain is rough (rocks and roots) but that is to be expected.
Very easy hike, good views. Good to see once, but I probably won't do this one again. Lots of bunchberries, blueberries, and juniper. And the drive through the Keltic Lodge area was beautiful.

Great family friendly trail! Amazing ocean views with some ups and downs. After reaching the red chairs if you complete loop instead of going back the same way be prepared for some brush on the trail. (Had to duck under so my daughter in the back carrier didn’t get a branch to the face!)
Trail was well groomed with many side trails for great look-offs. It was a bit misty the day we went but it was a great walk/hike. : >

This is such a scenic and enjoyable hike. Interesting history, well maintained and fairly easy to walk. Great views of Cape Smokey as well as to both. Lots of sea birds at head. One of my favs! Just park at Kentucky Lodge; easy to find
Great hike - lots of ups & downs, but completely worth it - spectacular!!!
Very Scenic
Nice trail, great views.
absolutely beautiful, just walked it yesterday  easy trail and worth every second, take all the little paths off to the side you can get really great pics
Be prepared. Icy on northeast side of peninsula. Packed snow and ice. Take crampons or it’s gonna be a difficult hike back to trail head.

Signs to Keltic lodge didn't match app directions. App refused to send Lifeline despite connectivity. Part I did was beautiful but part to lodge in park, not in app, had deep snow, no human footprints.
Beautiful during all seasons, a must see during the winter!
amazing in wintertime! Didn't see anybody. little piece of heaven on earth!
Nicely groomed trail. Great for family walks.
Cloudy walk with Ty and Max
Easy with a nice payoff.
It was beautiful! Can be done fast at a quick pace :)

Lovely 2.5 mile loop trail offering a wide variety of gentle up and down terrain and gorgeous water views. Convenient parking at trailhead or at Celtic Lodge Parking Lot. Trail does have some rocky areas and roots - hiking stick helpful!
fabulous!
nice mellow hike with great lookoffs! some side trails will bring you to bushwack if you're stubborn
Nice little hike out to the point. Great views along the way too.

I will assume the loop is fine.  the odd rock and root. the straight out and in is heavily rocked and rooted.  not for those with poor depth perception and fear of misstepping. down hill was horrible. up hill was better because I was more sure of my footing.

next time I will do with proper hiking boots and a walking pole.
Awesome family hike

A really beautiful and easy hike. there were lots of lookouts just off the trail and it’s easy to stay and take photos. I would recommend doing Franey and Middlehead together as a nice hiking morning or afternoon.
Magnificent views; easy hike.

This has been my favourite trail so far; very easy for the kids but still some small inclines and declines throughout the well walked path. Some very close cliff drops throughout and the most amazing views.
Easy hike for family. Very nice views, short walk! Well maintained
I would call this one moderate. There were some hills and the national park refers to it as moderate. We did it on a hot day and water was definitely required.
Great vies at the end.... the day we went was bit overcast... yet we still had super views :D
Short easy trail with magnificent views and birds at the end.

Beautiful trail. Nice and easy so good for kids and dogs. Watch your footing in some of the rocky areas. 
Views are beautiful.
Easy trail with beautiful views
Heads up on Middle Head; it’s lovely but was closed while we were here- June 2020. Check Highland National Park, Parks  Canada  before you go.

Very pretty trail with some great coastal scenery. There are a number of scenic lookouts and areas to explore, with a couple of them were overgrown with downed trees. Can also get muddy in areas. This trail is probably on the harder end of easy difficulty as it has a few small hills as well as a rocky area or two.
great trail
beautiful views even in the rain
This was our end of day hike (the third hike of the day).  It was a great way to finish the day...relatively easy with great views.
Fantastic views!  Fairly simple hike with a few hills but nothing difficult.  Many great viewing sections.

Great intro to the Cabot trail. This narrow neck of land juts well out to the sea, allowing some perspective on the regional geography and topography.  Easy path, well marked and maintained with numerous vantage points and beautiful views over sea cliffs to south across the bay to  Cape Smokey; Ingonish island and mountains across the bay to the north.
Beautiful hike !  Another one that wasn’t just about getting to a destination, but enjoying views all along. Easy.

Toller weg. Startet früh morgens. Sonst ist es sehr u

Beautiful hike with several gorgeous overlooks. Not overly difficult but more challenging than Skyline.
Beautiful views of the ocean.
My favorite trail.  Good for all levels. Spectacular views and an interesting history.
Wow!

Easy hike overall, with lots of opportunities to branch off the main path for lookouts. Ending view was lovely, very scenic, though can get quite windy and cool depending on the conditions that day, so dress accordingly. Good footwear recommended as there are lots of roots on the trail.

Easy quick trail with nice views along the way. Rained and was foggy the day we did it so our views were a bit limited but still nice. Some areas were a bit slick due to the weather but on a nice day proper footwear wouldn't really be a concern.
Wonderful views, relatively easy hike. Loop back is great!
Well maintained trail, pretty good views of the coast.  Drive through the hotel, parking lot is in the back.
Easy hike with stunning views
Beautiful views on this trail. Doesn't take overly long so a stop while touring the Cabot Trail is worth it. Make sure to wear proper footwear even though the hike is pretty easy.

Nice trail, fairly easy but a lot of people seem to think that means flip flops or high heels will be fine.  The trail is rock and root or dirt, very little in the way or boardwalks.  It does tend to be busy through the summer, it is a highly promoted trail in this part of the park.
Amazing views, definitely worth the time to stop when touring the Cabot Trail.
Stunning cliff top views and easy forest paths. Mostly solid terrain with a couple rockier rough patches, many small hills. Very windy!
Agree with all the other reviews - great trail, spectacular views. My second favourite walk in the Cape Breton park!
Great trail to the point which has spectacular views. Well worth a side trip - my second favourite walk in Cape Breton.

An easy trail with great views. The trail can be quite busy as it is close to the park entrance. Even so, there are sections where you will still experience the “alone in the wilderness” vibe. The trail is mostly flat with a few inclines and declines. I wore hiking boots but you could easily do it in sneakers or birkenstocks and you would be fine.
Great trail. Relatively easy.
Fun hike through forests and around the point which opens up to a great sea view. Be sure to take the wide loop upon return to get a break from other hikers.
Wonderful trail with steep rugged sections and some narrow sections. fantastic view at the end.
This was a fun hike with great views!  Well travelled though, very popular ie crowded.
Nice quick trail at end of day. We completed this one after a late dinner to work off my large fish and chip plate.
great trail for families.  easy for all. scenic.
Great views...
Nice trail with many ocean look out points. There are a few places to go down to the water. A lot of bugs, bring bug spray. The Keltic lodge nearby also has good ocean view.
Easy trail with great views at the end! It gets very crowded, so get there early!
So pretty. Lots of little offshoot paths for great photo ops.

Difficult trail with constant steep inclines and declines throughout the trail. We had a dog on leash with us and I wouldn’t recommend if you have a dog that pulls on leash as it can make the steep declines stressful! Beautiful look offs at multiple points along the trail :) We managed to get turned around on ourselves down by Eunice Lake so added an extra couple kms as a result. I notice this mentioned in other reviews too so make sure you continue around to the right of the lake! (If you do the loop where you enter at the 1.7k mark from the main trail)
Great trail, difficult hike, a bit overgrown in some areas

This has been our favorite trail so far!  ended up 7.5 miles.  it was difficult in the heat but the views and the hike were perfect!  there are several large elevation changes so be prepared for climbing and footing issues.  took us about 3 hours and 15 minutes.  the views!
well marked but it got long

Great day hike! Sturdy and supportive footwear is recommended
Some parts are a bit rough / overgrown about half way, for about 1km or so. lil scratchy but not bad. Otherwise awesome
Great day hike
Loved it!! My favourite yet!

great trail and plenty challenging. difficulty is accurate but if you are sure-footed and agile it's nothing to worry about. as an experienced and aggressive hiker it took 2 hours 10 mins. A rough terrain, and some areas of thick overgrowth.  Nice trail for fir adults..
Great trail with many look offs. Definitely want to bring the bug spray for this one.

A nice difficult trail. Lots of steep inclines, tree roots and rocks but incredible look-offs, a rock formation you can go through along the path, and beautiful lake views. Definitely bring water and take your time but well worth it. Of note, there are a few damp areas and really overgrown spots on the trail so bug spray is a must.

great trail! definitely one of the harder ones i’ve done out here. the trails were well marked and it wasn’t too busy. the trails did fit a little narrow at some points so it was hard passing by people. overall great hike!

Great trail! Lots of elevation change. DO NOT park on Bayer mill road. Had a visit with the local RCMP. No parking signs all over. Park on park road or the arena RCMP suggested. Hit up the food truck Thursday to Sunday beer garden as well!
Awesome trail. Took me over four hours to complete the loop but I stopped at each look off.
Challenging and varied hike with lots of up and down and beautiful views.
blackflies are out!  leaves are popping!  trail in good shape with just a few muddy spots.
Amazing trail! Great trail markers too.

Beautiful trail, took 2.5/3 hours with breaks to complete, not the 4-5 hours the sign recommends. This is coming from a moderately/average fit person. 

Very up hill hike but with stunning views. Went in a chilly and kind of rainy day without issue. Can’t imagine it in the sunlight!

Amazing trail.. well marked which I 
love especially when flying solo. 
views were spectacular. I chose to head up at the 1.7 km on the rail trail heading in. Glad I did. It was easier going down the softer terrian at the other end by Jessies dinner than it would have been going down all the boulders at the first. 
heading back over the next few weeks to tackle the North and South Granite trails.

Beautiful lookouts...we started this from the opposite end from what most do and challenged ourselves to alot of incline. Been lots of rain in the last 24 hours and this trail surprizingly drained well!  ...not alot of mud.  There's lots of rock and root...so it was slippery. I wouldn't rate this difficult but it wasn't easy either. Loved it!
Dry route. Nice weather. Great view.
wet!!  definitely wear boots after wet weather.
Not for beginners.bring good shoes
Well marked and easy to follow. This trail is well maintained and offers some great views.

conditions are great.
a little wet in a few small spots.

What a great trail, no ice today at all. Very easy to navigate, many trail markers and easy to spot. From the parking lot and back at Park rd we went 11 kms, and was over 4 hours (with some stops). Check out all the lookouts, so worth it!

Beautiful trail, ugly conditions.

Had to give up on Admirals Lake due to ice, and the railbed was a mix of slush and ice, but the area is beautiful and, under any other conditions, would easily be a 5-star hike.
such a beautiful day on one of my favorite trails!  pretty chilly, still a few icy snow patches left but easily passable with a little care.
absolutely beautiful! no complaints! *(other than my phone dying at the very end making it seem like an 8.3k walk.. but its definitely 9.3k!)* highly suggested!
Icy but ok with cramp ons, beautiful day and fantastic views. Saw no one on the trail, very quiet
Amazing views ! Must do again in 6 months
Great! Lots of ups and downs. Snow was a bit slippery.
lots of snow but fairly packed down path.

Love this trail! The trail is challenging and the views are beautiful. Packed snow, some icy parts. Lots of ups and downs. Well marked. I was able to do it without spikes, but enjoyed it more once I put them on. It took us a little over 3 hours with a few stops at all the look offs. Will definitely do it again!
Beautiful! Trail is mainly packed snow with a few slippery and icy patches but I did fine in boots without spikes. Trees keep you out of the wind which is perfect. Really fun trail
Beautiful trail. Highly recommend
Amazing trek.. well worth it
Loved this trail.  It’s well marked.  The lookout points were stunning. My legs are feeling the burn as it’s not an easy one, but it’s a great workout and just a beautiful hike overall
Icy but beautiful.
Great hike. Great views from various look offs.

great trail.
one of my faves.
perfect balance of moderate and challenging terrain.
It was awesome!  Great workout and beautiful scenery. Definitely a do again!
Amazing! Beautiful views!
great hike... you will deal with traffic as this is well known trail system.
Many awesome views but trail should be rated difficult! Worth it, though.

Did the trail in early November. It was 8 degrees out and nice and dry despite being overcast. Not a trail I would recommend if it was wet out, between the leaves and roots it would border on being dangerous. However, it was a nice dry trail. If you start on the Southern end, the hardest part of the entire trail is the first 1km. It’s quite steep on the other end as well, but the southern end has a lot of rocks and roots to traverse. I looked forward to doing this trail for a while now. There are some amazing views from the top of the trail, but the highlight of my hike was Eunice Lake. There wasn’t a breath of wind the entire hike so when I arrived at Eunice Lake, it looked like a mirror!  What a spectacular view. The trail head says to allow 5 hours and the maps provided on the trail say 4-5 hours. The main trail is 5.5km long and took me just under 2 hours hiking by myself. I ran into some others that said it took 2.5 hours.  All in all, a really nice hike. Take lots of water and some snacks for energy.
Great condition, the parking on Bayers Mill is a good idea, take out a couple km of rail trail.

This is the second year in a row doing this hike! It's not an easy one, but not too difficult either, lots of rock climbing so wear proper footwear, a few look offs which had really nice views! Trail is marked the whole way, but there was one part where  the trees over gown down by the lake, where we missed the marker, and didn't realize we did a circle, so took us probably 15 mins longer this time, you have to go down right to the lake and go to the right! Took us just under 5 hours to complete, including a a stop for lunch and a few other stops .
It was a bit difficult for my second hike but felt pretty good that I completed the trail.
Awesome but difficult
Could be cut back in some spots but great hike
Trail is a bit over grown in some sections. But someone has cleared a bunch recently. Great views
Great trail. Dog friendly. I've jogged it in an hour so take the 4-5 hour rating with a grain of salt if you're able bodied and not stopping for breaks.

Really great trail! the woods were beautiful and I saw a very friendly deer. I went a day after it rained so there were mosquitoes but as long as I kept at a steady pace they didnt bother me (I wasn't wearing bug spray). Also didnt find any ticks on me or my dog so that's a plus. The signage was very good, lots of little yellow reminders that you're on the right trail. The rocks were a bit slippery at some parts so definitely make sure you're wearing hiking shoes. Also, park at the end of Bayer Mill road, otherwise you're going to be walking on flat boring trail for 2km.

Great trial if you're looking for more of a challenge due to the rocky terrain. Elevation gain is steady with some steep sections but beautiful payoff at the top. The sign says 4 to 5 hours at 45km per hour but it only took me 3 hours going at a moderate pace. After you get to the lookout point you can choose to do a small look that goes by Admiral Lake or you can just turn back the way you've come because the trail is really just an out and back with a loop attached and the view at Admiral Lake was not totally worth it.

We did this hike for Canada Day, and it was hot! Lots of mozzies and flies out, and humid. The terrain is difficult with lots of rocks and roots that were slippery. Moderate elevation. Really great look outs and views! My favorite part was squeezing through a boulder structure. Great hike, but maybe not for 25+ days

Did this trail on Saturday June 20th and would of loved it if it wasn't for the heat. This is a difficult trail with amazing views and look off points. Would highly recommend for anyone looking for a challenge. I brought alot of water and would recommend others do the same.
Did this trail yesterday, and it was quite difficult! Well marked trail full of up and downs. Lots of cool look offs, but there was no stopping because the bugs were so bad!

Great trail - I would rate it as moderate to difficult as there are some steep hills, slippery spots and a little climbing required. Took about 3 hours from start to end. Very well marked and well maintained. Will definitely be returning to try the other hikes within the system.

What a great loop! Definitely accurately rated as difficult with steep inclines and declines, lots of large rock on the trail. An excellent challenge. Perfect evening loop to see the sun setting. Would recommend starting by 5. At a decent pace it is easily done in under 3 hours. Very little mud and only encountered one other person on the loop trail. Definitely going to go back!  A must do, in the fall, as the views will be amazing.

Well marked and a very scenic walk through the forest with several look-off points. Lots of inclining trail which was a great challenge. Light traffic on a weekday midday - we encountered 4 other groups and a few others along the main path leading to the trail loops. Will hope to get out again in Fall to experience the views.
awesome trail, but pretty challenging! dogs loved it and we didn’t run into too many other people.  will be back for sure!

Great trail for a Thursday afternoon hike.  The rail trail at the beginning was very busy, however we quickly lost the crowds once getting on the trail.  When walking down the rail trail from the parking lot, the entrance to the Admiral Lake Loop is an unmarked off shoot into the woods with red and yellow markers nailed to the trees (Admiral Lake Loop is the yellow markers).  We accidentally missed the entrance and ended up doing the loop backwards.

Make sure you take the ~20m side trail labeled 'Janet's Diner' - great spot for lunch!

It took our group of 2 + dog (on leash) approximately 3 hours to complete the loop including the 5km of rail trail with a half hour lunch in the middle.  Icy sections on a lot of the ascents and descents, but plenty of snow and rock exposed enough to avoid needing to use microspikes.

This was an awesome hike! Did it in the middle of the winter so it was quite icy. Lots of steep hills but was rewarded with great views. I did the admiral lake loop, and the skull rock lookoff.  Was about 11 km and took me and my golden retriever just over 2 hours to complete although we were moving quick and only stopped to look at the views. The signage for admiral lake loop recommends 4-5 hours for the trail which I thought was a bit much
challanging trail, lots of steep climbing,  beautiful look offs make all the climbing well worth it. Well marked trail, a little muddy in spots.

Great trail, nice views on some of the smaller trails to look-offs. 
Was a fair bit of people using it, lots of up and down, but nothing too challenging if you are in good shape.

Started from the Bayers Mill Rd entrance to avoid the large trailhead. Hiked this with my 3 month old strapped to me, my frenchie and my friend and her 2 pups. Kept a moderately fast pace. Amazing trail, had such a nice hike. Perfect in this season to see all of the colours. Definitely in the intermediate/advanced category, not a hike for unfit people. We powered through the entire thing and was well worth it. So many stops along the way for stunning scenery and overlooking the forests and lakes.

Loved it!  After a heavy rain overnight the trail was magical.  Rich moss, lichen and. ferns in full force.  Blueberry treats along the way, great overlooks.  Not for the less than fit hiker.  Lots of rocks and roots and long sections of dense bushes to get through.

Love this hike. Steep inclines and declines. Lots of rock climbing. Stunning views. Over grown sections but still very easy to follow the trail. The cave is awesome and very unique. Took us 2.5 hours but sign estimates 45min a km.
It was a cool trail but hard on the knees.
A little bit hard, but the view is definitely worth it.

I’ll definitely bring my wife and daughter out to experience this one. The trail seems well kept, marked with yellow indications every few meters and that makes it nearly impossible to step off the trail and get lost.

It’s amazing trail. I would recommend it as it is really moderate compared to most of the moderate trails in Nova Scotia. Most of the time you walk into forest but several amazing views make the trail really beautiful.

Great hike with my dog. Beautiful elevation and views with lakeside spots as well. One of my new favorites around the city!
Such a good little hike that’s all up hill to the look off aka skull rock and then a nice way back all the way down!

The Admiral Lake Loop was a great hike, it's very rough natural terrain, every vista was beautiful. Took us about  4 hours to complete it, I cannot wait to go again.

would recommend trying out on both low and high tide

Beautiful trail, stunning views. Muddy in some places, but totally worth it.
Great trail, lovely hike along the atlantic ocean!!

Very beautiful. Within about 10 min, you’re out in the open and overlooking the Atlantic. Look for seals on the rock island formations you’ll see when you’re first able to see the ocean (they can be very hard to see unless you look very carefully, or have binoculars). From there, you just walk down Gannet Ln, hop over the car barricade, and turn right into the bush when you see the sign that says “trail”. Great trails! No markers but there's enough carved out that you will find your way one way or another. Beautiful spots to stop and rest on the rocks and look out over the ocean! Lots of different terrains so be prepared for anything and you'll be good! Muddy in some spots today but to be expected this time of year.

Hiked about 3km to the bunker, round trip was just over 6km. muddy in some spots but it was sunny and beautiful. watched some fishing boats bring in lobster traps. First time on this trail it was pretty busy! amazing views we'll definitely do it again.

Me and my homie said screw it let’s go sunset chasing together. It was a bit cold and windy off the water so it was hard to light the joint but a lot of cool rocks for chilling out. Overall Duncan’s Cove was incredible views of the water and someone’s mansion, I’d recommend checking out for sure.
Absolutely beautiful views!! So stunning. Trail was quite icy in sections, at times micro spikes were a good idea. Icy wind but worth it!

If you’re bushwhacking, you’ve missed the trail and, since some of this is protected, you should turn back and find the trail. 

Beautiful coastal views, funky ww2 bunkers, not marked but easy to follow trail so long as you get the actual trailhead. 

BE RESPECTFUL OF PRIVATE PROPERTY. This little community has dealt with a lot of BS from hikers trespassing and, if we all want to be allowed on the trail at all, we all must be respectful.

I’m actually super disappointed, and I was really looking forward to this hike for quite some time. The end views are incredible, but the hike in is horrendous. 

As others have mentioned, Google maps marks the trailhead at Gannet Lane which is on private property. So the All Trails trailhead is where we started (which is also a challenge to find as there is no signage). I only had a “trail” for about 1km in, the rest is marsh and bushes. I followed the All Trails map as there are 0 signs on the hike, and it was knee deep swamp for more than half of the hike today. Maybe I went off the actual trail somehow? If that’s the case then the All Trails map is grossly wrong. Or maybe we’ve just had a ton of rain lately. 

What should have been a 2 hour hike took about 3 1/2 with very limited time on the rocks as we knew we had a big journey back to the car.
Excellent condition, amazing views. A classic walk! Plus, we got the news that Biden won while on our walk. Big￼ celebration!!!!

It’s a beautiful coastal trail with old historic bunkers and breathtaking views of the ocean! Some bushwhacking, many wet spots, and some parts of the trail are along the cliffs so be prepared. Such an inspiring hike. Terry Sheppard(a review just below mine) gave the best directions for finding the trail head.
beautiful views, fun trail, lots to see
Beautiful trail. Beautiful scenery along the ocean

This is probably one of the best coastal trails we have in NS, and that is saying something. The trail is not maintained but easy to follow. Once you get to the coast, you just follow along it until you reach the abandoned bunker. 

The real challenge is finding the trail entrance. The app will take you to a trail head no one uses. Everyone goes in off Gannet Lane although it is a private road. 

You go along Ketch Harbour Rd. to Chebucto Head Rd. And then turn on Duncan’s Cove Road. If it is a nice day on the weekend, there will likely be line of cars parked along the side of the road. There is a house at the end with a “private property” sign up. Gannet Lane is a dirt road off to the right. There is another house at the end of that lane with a “private property” sign up. Here is where it is tricky to find the trail head. It is right by a power pole. I’ve posted a picture. There are a couple little trails that all merge together eventually. 

There is very little bushwhacking on the trail. You are out in the open for the vast majority of the hike, so sun screen and hats in the summer. You are right along the coast so it is windy. 

The hike ends at an old army bunker. Well, there is a long rock wall about 5 - 10 minutes away that you can see from the bunker. There is a huge private home behind the rock wall. 

This is definitely a moderate hike with lots of ups and down. We did see some dogs and children along the way. They can do it with some help. There are a number of spots that you are right by the cliff so keep a careful eye. 

Took us 1 hour and 22 minutes on the way in, stopping for pictures and enjoying the scenery. 1 hour and 4 minutes on the way out without many stops. It’s about 6 kilometres.

Such a beautiful area. The sea breeze, the sounds of the waves, just so nice. 

it's a pretty easy hike
Love this trail. Have done many times to enjoy the view.
Great hike! Not very strenuous and amazing views! WW2 bunkers were very neat!

The trail itself is clear but prone to muddiness after bad weather. There are various routes you can take (either scrambling over rocks closer to the shore or heading through trodden paths in the trees and bushes). 

If you start on Gannet Lane then there is quite a steep climb down at the start of the trail. The start of the trail is clearly marked by a wooden sign on a power line just before the private house. 

The views are beautiful in all weather. Due to the up-and-down over the rocks, I would agree that this trail is moderate and you should come prepared with sturdy footwear and water. 

This trail is not maintained.
Grown over and neglected. Very wet after weeks of no rain. Did not even bother to complete the trail it was so sub par to other trails around.
A little over grown  hard to find trails
So much mud!

Amazing view. It's a little mucky at the start and once you're through to the water you can avoid most wet spots by using the rocks.  It can occasionally get slippery but we had a great time. My kids loved the climb.
One of my favourites! Can be wet in the spring so bring good boots.
Super nice. Bring pants and extra socks for swampy areas.

Today was my first time at this trail and I absolutely loved it. very clean and most of the dogs I have seen were on leashes.  
in some areas around the trail it was very muddy, so make sure you wear proper shoes for your hike :)
Beautiful view, I would definitely go again. It was kind of confusing to find at first.

We parked at the turnaround near Duncan's Cove and Chebucto Head Roads and walked back to the trailhead on the oceanside marked by yellow nature preserve signs. Mid-March we ran into flooded sections every 5 min and only made it 2km in. On the way home we saw lots of cars parked at the lighthouse turnoff and Duncan's Cove Rd at Gannet Ln, mind the no parking signs, it would must be an easy walk from there to the oceanside. The easiest way to get to it is to park by the gate to the lighthouse and walk up the road to the lighthouse. On your right you will see one of the old Bunkers, follow the trail down to them and it continues around.
