There is a trail there that is about 2km of wooded/marsh trail and then becomes coastal taking you to the Lighthouse where you can continue to the Duncan's Cove trail and then just take the road back to your vehicle
Great views, neat old buildings.  Many different ways to go as the trail is not marked so I went 2 different ways.  Awesome hike!
Beautiful views of the coastal barrens. Found the trails further from the coast quite muddy. Need good shoes for navigating the rock near shore. I would definitely go back again.

Beautiful! Took about 3 hours spent total, 2 there because we were exploring and enjoying the view and 1 hour back because we were hungry. 
Bring water and snacks! Easy walking on the trail and easy enough to follow but better to stay in the main trail. Wear good shoes for hiking and bring layers since the wind can make it cold. Worth the trip!
The first bay is Duncan’s cove and then there is duck reef and Eastern Cove which is the biggest, the end is Gill’s Cove where you can see the lighthouse and get some shield from the wind behind the bunker.
Beautiful views.  Can be very busy
Amazing view, nice hike. The old forts are neat. Watch your step.

Really beautiful hike along the water. Rocky terrain, just a couple of muddy spots. Saw a large group of seals on Duncan Reef. Trail is not marked, but quite easy to follow. Well populated hiking route.
ocean view hike, absolutely beautiful on a sunny day

Beautiful trail with amazing ocean views the entire hike. Got to pass 2 sea caves (could hear them only, not really see them) comparable to the Thunder Hole in Maine. No parts of the trail were muddy and was easy to find the way to the look out station as you could see it a few km ahead in the distance. This a trail we decided to leave our dog home for and I’m glad we did. My opinion: this trail is not suitable for dogs - extremely sharp rocks/rough terrain, thorn bushes, and steep drop offs. An accident could easily occur, however people seem to think this is an off-leash free for all. Could be a bad situation if an on or off leash dog approached another as the trail is extremely narrow in places, often on the edge of a drop off.

Aside from that this is the most beautiful and enjoyable hike we’ve done in NS to date. There was beautiful scenery at all times. My opinion: this is a much better and more diverse trail than Cape Split. The hike took us under 3 hours to complete (including two 10-min breaks, and a 25-min break for lunch at the end). 

Note: parts of the trail require a bit of maneuvering/slight rock climbing.
This trail is beautiful. Can be very tricky to follow as the trail is mainly human made but definitely my favourite in Nova Scotia!!

Forced to turn back halfway through (before the reportedly spectacular ocean views) as the trail disappeared into a bog interspersed with pools. Prior to that there were multiple boggy/muddy sections that made for very slow going. Overall, a miserable aborted hike. If you care about preserving the environment do not attempt this trail for the foreseeable future.

Depending on how you go about it (I’ve done a couple different routes now) - parts can be a bit overgrown and you can lose track of the path when really wet (I most recently went in spring after a LOT of rain)... so also be prepared for your feet to get wet if you aren’t wearing waterproof hikers. I wouldn’t recommend doing this in sandals or flip flops. Great visits overlooking the Atlantic out at the mouth of the harbour.
All swamp and bogey

*THIS IS A NATURE RESERVE - NOT A PARK*
The trail is NOT managed. There are no facilities and no signage.
It is protected under Nova Scotia’s Special Places Protection Act.
This means that the habitats and species are vulnerable to disturbance and damage; recreation is restricted. 
Dogs must be kept on leash and stay on trail at all times.  
All fires, camping, hunting, trapping, motorized AND non-motorized vehicle access are prohibited (that means no ATVs, motorcycles, or mountain bikes, or strollers).
Hikers should stay on the main trail and follow LEAVE NO TRACE principles.
And beware of Black-legged ticks!
A gorgeous coastline hike with seals and tides.

Stunning ocean and tide views on a partly cloudy and breezy Sunday. For a NW wind, waves and tides were still eye-catching and loud. Highly recommend for semi-agile people and dogs, the further you go the more tougher the terrain. Overall, a great active hike along a gorgeous coast line.

I enjoyed this trail, was absolutely beautiful. A little tricky is places due to rough terrain and mud but that’s a part of hiking and part of the adventure. I’ve never done this hike before so I’m not sure if it’s always quite wet or if it’s just because it’s spring and wet anyway but I’d recommend extra socks and shoes for after. Also, if you’re someone you needs to use washroom regularly it’s not a great spot. No outhouses (which is noted) but also no trees to hind behind. Lol
I did the trail on a foggy day. Hands down one of the best hikes I have done in Nova Scotia. The entire trail hugs the rugged coastline making for incredible views. Will definitely do it again
great hike, and amazing views. the trail was very boggy and muddy. But it's a time of year issue I'm guessing.
Great walk out to army shack and back . January 27 2019 plus 4!
Went in mid- November. Trail still good but a bit muddy. Definitely need sturdy boots- lots of rocks and uneven terrain. Coastline views are spectacular. Well worth it.
A gorgeous hike right on the ocean - highly recommended!

Very busy trail and easy to walk past the trailhead. Aside from that this is an easy trail for anyone to walk and the views are absolutely amazing. We saw seals wading in the surf the day we were there. There's lots to explore here so make sure you have a lot of time!
definitely my favorite coastal trail with lots of elements, you will never get bored aha!
This is one of our favorite hikes.Views are amazing and variety of terrain just right

Easy, heavily used trail with great views of the rugged coastline.  We were lucky enough to see 10 to 12 seals playing in the surf breaking around several rocky islands just offshore.  Private property so be respectful.  It's also a nature preserve so minimize your impact!
My favourite hike. Beautiful views and lots of opportunity for adventure.

Great hike! Beautiful views all the way, gorgeous fauna and lots of places to stop and let the dogs have some water. Loved the variation of trail from open flat rocks to short steep stints to deep forest and windy trails through lush plant life. Our dogs had no problem with this hike, just took it slow to allow for breaks and water. 3 hrs round trip with our breaks.

Great views along the entire trail. Some boggy areas, but managed not to ruin my boots. Some steep climbs and ascents. Be sure to wear appropriate footwear. Entrance to trail can be confusing. Weathered  sign says ‘Private Property’ and there is a low gate to hop over.

Great views all along the trail. Just about 20-30 mins from Halifax. The first bit in the north part of the trail goes through some private property where no vehicles are allowed, but it looks like many people go through it to get onto the trail anyways
We saw sea lions just off the shore. Trail is quite muddy in parts!
Very scenic.
Really enjoyed this trail. Not overly challenging and beautiful views of Nova Scotia’s rugged coastline. Will definitely be back to do this hike over, and over again.
Amazing trail, with a wide verity of scenery it has something for everybody, and depending on how brave you are, many small rock beaches to explore
Beautiful hike with stunning views!!! Terrain can be a bit muddy/soggy so make sure to have good footwear!

Absolutely beautiful hike.  You will see waves crashing on the shore, rolling hills, woods, cliffs and even bunkers that were built for WWII.  The scenery is breath-taking.  Use a little caution and be sure to wear proper hiking shoes as there are a few areas of difficult terrain.
This was a spectacular hike! The view!

Once you get to the abandoned ww2 observation station, you must turn around. There is a 1000 foot long boulder wall beyond, with a number of No Trespass signs. If you stray, you will be on  private property and damaging vulnerable flora and interfering with wild life that the owners are feeding and encouraging. Please respect the flora and fauna and turn back to Duncan's Cove. Yuu'll be surprised at the new things you see on the trip back to where you started!
Very nice trail, a good work out !
Beautiful views and great terrain...definitely one of my favorites! :-)
good stuff. a little rough through the ash lake trail, but overall a solid hike! more of a workout which I enjoy.
great trail, well marked with maps - lookout is awesome, lake is totally swimmable !
Awesome trail. Great camp out locations

Short areas are very muddy or flooded but that's to be expected given the recent weather. A little buggy but not too bad, and well worth it for the beauty, birds, and berries—all of which distracted me and lengthened my hike :)
Great hiking trail!
Good hike. Phone was very helpful as the trail can be confusing at points

Great trail. The ash lake part of the loop is the easiest part. Lots of rocks and roots all the way. If your not familiar with the blue mountain wilderness series of trails make sure you have your maps on your phone.
Great but bring your phone. This app helps as there are so many confusing spots.

great trail enjoyed it very much with Ashley...did a bit of bush waking and went around Charlie lake and back to the can was a great trip for after work ...

great trail! lots of variation. Not crazy busy. good look out points. Parking lot was full but we didn't run in to many people. Bring bug spray! Marshy muddy spots, maybe not the best for people with mobility issues. We had a great time.
Loved this trail, first part is definitely crowded and we found it sometimes annoying to navigate, but once you get away from the parking lot it is great
Great trail with uneven terrain. Very crowded, especially closer to the start. Nicer once you get up by Ash lake though.
Great condition, muddy at parts. Perfect temp.
Slushy and wonderful
Amazing day after a snow fall. Trails were in good condition, snow added some traction over the ice. Not many people out for a sunny +6° day.
Icy
Still icy in places, starting to melt  spring is in the air
good trail, veeeery icy and somewhat hard to navigate.
Good woods walk near the city, nice narrow walking trails well marked. Too busy people wise for me but not so bad when you venture farther out,, but i did go on a holiday, so what was i thinking.
so beautiful as always, and even with all the thawing it wasn't too muddy, and the few muddy places were easy to get around by going slightly off trail.
Amazing

Another lovely hike in this area, but the scattered sunlight had made the trodden paths very icy, so grabbing branches and walking on roots and granite were the only ways to stay upright. 

Such varied terrain and some steeper slopes. Trails are fairly easy to see but aren’t always accurate to the map. The trails to Fox Lake are signed and obvious
so beautiful with all the snow! very icy for the first bit but it gets better.
Trail was great, lots of people on the front half
Beautiful day! Great trail, good condition.

the trails aren't marked all that well. there are a decent amount of 'you are here signs' but not much for tags along the trails.
cute little spot with a bridge at the end of hobson lake
was an awesome hike. lots of everything from easy sections to hard. And beautiful views. But I would recommend using GPS as alot of the trail markers and signs  have been torn down.
Not a park, this is a wilderness area. Please wear blaze so hunters can see you!! Enjoy :)

Beautiful trail. Really varied in views with the lake and option to head up to the look off (well worth it). Some areas are not well marked. We veered off the path a few times as we were following ribbon marked trees. Had to rely on the app a number of times to right our course. Would come back now that we are more familiar with the trail. Areas closer to the parking lot were busy. Once you get into the deeper sections it was very peaceful.

The trail has lots of up and down and roots/rocks. Really pretty views from a look off, and nice sections along water. We started off well but ended up finding ourselves off trail a couple of times, one time that added quite a bit of time to the afternoon as we found ourselves out of the woods and along an atv trail that was a mud pit. The trail isn’t well marked. We saw a few other groups once we got back on trail that had the same issues. All in all it was a nice hike and would go back, I’m just glad we started early enough that we had time to take a wrong turn before losing daylight.

Similar in length to the first loop of the bluff. But not as well marked or trafficked. Great run regardless.

Challenging, easy to get lost. I used the navigation through the app and unless I was looking at it, it was easy to go down a path that wasn’t part of the loop. Rocky and uneven but great nature hike and the lakes were beautiful.
great varied hike close to the city.

Lots of stumps and rocks on the terrain.  Wear solid footwear.   Nice view of lakes but mostly inland.  Solid walk.  Keep an eye on gps as you can get turned around easily.  We detoured to the look off and it was worth view.  Beautiful right here in the middle of the city.

Loved this trail! Great variety, not busy (only saw 5 people and 2 dogs on a Friday afternoon), Great Lake views. Will return. Would recommend wearing hiking boots and pants. My dog loved it too, especially swimming in the lakes.
Nice trail, dog friendly. The east side around Ash Lake is pretty overgrown so wear long pants and use tick spray. Easy trail but wear good footwear, lots of rocks and such.
Super nice trail, a couple nice lookoffs, not super hard to follow, although there is a misleading map sign (marked as 25, actually 15?) pretty sweet overall

Did this three times. In the winter it was extremely hard to follow, couldn’t really tell what was a path 
In the spring it was extremely wet.
Did it again a week ago and it was dry, easy to follow because of the foliage. It also has maps along the trail which makes this trail easy to follow
Awesome trail, didnt do the whole thing, stopped somewhere along fox lake with a great view and camped a couple nights. Very nice trail! Would go again

Great trail with nice lakes for the dog. We encountered very little traffic, a couple others with dogs and a few fishermen. 

The section after you travelled all the way around the lake and reconnect to the previous trail portion is currently very muddy. Recommend going right to the fox trail to return to Collins. It’s fun to go over all the logs through the mud but the dog needed a good swim to get clean. 

Trail conditions were great otherwise.

Great day for hiking. The trail was in good condition, a little muddy in spots. There was a nice breeze but if you stopped, the black flies were there in full force! Picked up a few geocaches along the way.
nice spot for an adventure, only downfall the black flies were really bad bring some bug spray!

Completed this last weekend. Great condition, awesome hike!

I started at the end of Collin rd took the wrong path and instantly was lost luckily I ended up on a scenic route to Charlie's lake which was lovely! Made it back to the fox lake trail and really enjoyed the unique hike to the fox lake look off, which was gorgeous! very rocky, rooty and can be steep. definitly not for small children.

More of a trail conditions update than a review, only a couple of muddy spots and they’re easily bypassed. Bugs were present but not horrible, probably caught the last of the black fly season.
Great hike. Can get busy on weekends. Good place for dogs. can get a bit swampy after rain
There was a bit of ice on the trail in the beginning, but overall condition is good with rare muddy places.
Tried this for first time - completely hard packed ice.  Not possible without crampoms.

I went after a big rain so it was a little soupy close to the lakes but someone had put down logs to walk across in most parts and even made a makeshift bridge out of fallen branches. I recommend going for sure, more of a moderate to easy hike and the trail is well walked on and easy to follow
Really enjoyed this trail. Especially the look off.
Hiked this trail May 2018 enjoyed it very much.
Some newly felled trees across trail on West side of Ash Lake, otherwise in great shape this spring.

Nice in the fall. Ash Lake is quiet and lovely. It's really good to record and compare with the map as the trails can be a little faint at times. There are tapes and paint at tricky spots though plus some signs. I didn't go the Hobson's Lake route but picked a different way in and back.
Favourite

You can also just do the Hobson's Lake Trail which takes about 1:15 for a quick but satisfying one.
Great trail, muddy in spots and a little hard to find the entrance but we eventually made it

After a couple days of rain, this trail was wet and a bit muddy but well worth every soaked foot we got ! Absolutely stunning scenery and pretty easy going along the rocky and marshy paths. If there was a way to give more than five stars, THIS trail would definitely warrant it !
Great trail. Note: covers very rocky beach and requires some up and down over boulders. Should have good technical walking ability and ability to scrabble up and down. Lots of great ocean views!
Very nice trail! Great day to do it! A few wet spots but will hike again
Rainy day hike and picnic to celebrate our 30th anniversary
what a beautiful trail!  the views are stunning. my husband likes to sketch and I hike the trail.  you can see boats and fisherman frequently. it can be muddy at times.

Nice scenic trail. Bit over grown in places. We walked the road a ways to make it a loop. Not sure I’d recommend that. The trail from the road back to the main trail was on private property and petered out at the end and was quite overgrown. But was pretty, just better as an out and back trail or with two vehicles.
New favourite!! Beautiful views
Beautiful views from the trail. After 1.5km the trail is overgrown so we decided to turn back.
Best shore trail yet this year. Moderate rating but not onerous. Seems popular and the scenic views explain that.
dog friendly nice little coastal walk! GPS can take you to wrong location but it’s super close by. Nice ocean views

Lovely coastal hike!!! A bit if scrambling over the rocks in places but that was by choice. Some muddy spots but with the planks of wood you can avoid the mud or walk around on the edge of it. Started the trail from Hages Lane and walked down to the other starting point. Lot of beautiful spots for photos. If you love the ocean and costal hiking be sure to include this one on your to-do list.
great.. bit soggy!
Really great trail! For those who might want to pick the length of their hike  walk out to the half way mark and walk back the whole way is gonna be magical

Wet windy weekday, not another soul. Great trail but dress in waterproof pants or prepare to get thoroughly soaked from the brush. Watch the slick rocks, of course this wouldn't be as much of a problem if it's a drier day!
Beautiful trail, not too busy either! Wear shoes you don’t mind getting wet and long pants, the trail is pretty overgrown in some spots.
Beautiful oceanside out and back trial. Pretty easy walking, just a bit muddy in spots.
awesome hike. Beautiful coastal scenery
Great trail, beautiful coastal scenery, moderate in difficulty, muddy in some parts (hiking shoes help lots vs sneakers). Not too busy on the trail today.
Nice trail. Easy walking. But lots of up and downs and great views even in the fog.
Awesome trail!
Great, but busy day on the trail!
Very nice views of the ocean, and it's not hard to walk either, just bring boots as parts the trail can get pretty muddy.

A beautiful trail with rewarding views the entire way. It’s relatively flat too. There’s not many people there but the ones who were had the friendliest dogs. 

About 2/2.5 hours there and back with a snack break. Make sure to put Dr Bill Freedman Nature Reserve into your Google maps to get there
Lovely views

Loved this hike!! Incredible views, easy to moderate terrain. A little bit of mud and small area of marshy wet land, but for the most part narrow path and rocks on the beach. Would recommend wearing hiking pants or thick jeans, as there are areas of walking between thorn bushes. Almost the entire hike is coastal, so pack layers as it was chilly when we arrived around 11am but warmed up through the hike. Definitely recommend this one!
Lovely hike

This was one beautiful moment after another. It was a lovely evening and really lucked out with the weather for mid April. Definitely a few muddy spots but nothing that we couldn't get around.  This trail is not marked at all and there are multiple little paths you could take. I was grateful for the app for the first little bit, not knowing where all the little trails went. It seems that no matter which path you are on, they continue to meet back up so just pick the less muddy route! It was simply beautiful walking the coast the whole trail.
Lovely trail along the hills adjacent to the water near Prospect Village. Watch your footing and dodge some boggy patches but all on all a great walk.
Good rugged ramble over the rocks on a breezy spring day

High Head trail needs more love. I don’t know how this was my first time hiking it. You’re walking by the water the entire time basically. The views were great and I was accompanied by a sweet girl to top it off. Recommend to all friends
I absolutely enjoyed the coastal views here. If you enjoy coastal hiking then this trail is worth exploring. It’s best to go on warm days, anytime from early Spring to early Summer.
Great little out and back along the coast!
Really great coastal and grassy paths. Lots to look at and easy to be away from other people. Waterproof hikers a must !
The trail is great, very easy to follow and no ice or snow now.  It was a very windy day, but the scenery was fantastic.

hiking along the shore on rough well traveled trail with beautiful views both inland and offshore.  hiking boots recommended.

loop back along road or backtrack.
Definitely one of my new favourites! Little busy, but beautiful coastal views. Clear path but rocky and a bit icy.
Pretty day and the ocean was showing off.
Beautiful views, easy trail to follow.
Trail as advertised, beautiful panoramic views of bay and ocean.
Good hike, stayed more to the rocks along the water. Nice views, quite windy!
This hike as some pretty awesome views and some windy shores! The trail is well travelled and the sights are gorgeous! It even leads you to the town!
Gorgeous hike along panoramic coastal views. Saw a seal bobbing along the water close to shore. Had a picnic lunch perched on one of the many beautiful granite boulders.
Absolutely stunning views.  Some high grass areas that the path gets tight to walk through.
Wow. Stunning.
Nice views. A bit overgrown and uneven. I suggest wearing longer pants and sturdy shoes.
Loved it!  Great sea views without crowds!

Did it with my dog on a sunny Tuesday afternoon and only saw 2 other hikers and a few people fishing. Beautiful views. Not marked but easy to follow. Many parts of the trail are overgrown and you’re walking through tall grass, etc so if you’re concerned about ticks I’d wear long pants. Several geocaches out there.

July 2020. Prospect, Nova Scotia. Coastal trail along the shoreline. View of ocean, boats and seabirds. Rocky and dirt paths, some mud, some overgrowth (waist high bushes but path still visible). Mostly low level vegetation, very open, no shade. Busy during sunset near start of trail.

Just a warning that I did this trail last Sunday with my dog and she came home with 10+ porcupine quills in the side of her face.  Also very overgrown and bushy trail - would recommend pants and hiking boots.

Enjoyed a hot sunny day hiking this trail with friends (in our 50s 60s) for about 2 hours.  The views are spectacular and the hike fairly easy for all levels of ability.  There are a few boggy spots but some kind people have placed boards across for easier access.  There are beautiful flowers and what looks to be blue berries and maybe cranberries. Great trail! I didn’t have the best weather and couldn’t see much because of fog but am definitely planning to return!

Easy trail to hike. Beaches are rocky and unstable under foot but you can stay on the paths. Amazing views and lots of vegetation for enthusiasts. Take pole and fish for mackerel or just breath the air and relax along the shore.
Terrific trail. Plenty of rocks to climb, beach to comb, or stick to the trail and enjoy the view. Plan to visit at sunset. Best sunset view in Nova Scotia from the rocks. Amazing!
Awesome hike with beautiful views of the ocean. Easy, well worn path that is flat and very walkable for kids.
A fun easy trail .  takes 1.5hrs 1 way at a slow pace, with lots of coastal views.
Great trail. Beautiful scenic view. One of best spot to watch sunset in the city.
Great trail. Wet in places. The wind can be strong off the water. The views are incredible.  Can choose well travelled foot path or rock hop along the shore.
Great trail took the dogs out for a few hours. Sunny weather 16 degrees but glad we brought jackets with hoods due to the wind.
This is such an amazing trail. It’s very open and you can go off trail to the rocks to look at the ocean. View is amazing.
Beautiful brisk day
great scenery a lovely hike
Perfect hike for a sunny fall day! Lots of rocks and some roots so sturdy shoes are recommended. You are by the ocean most of the way so the views are amazing. Fairly level so a nice level hike.
Hiked this beautiful spot on a Sunday and it was not too busy! Gorgeous rocks and trails to explore. Trail was muddy in places but well worth the trip.
I loved this coastal trail! It was a beautiful view of the Atlantic almost the entire way — and was relatively flat! It’s nice and short too.
Mid to late august has some wild blackberries! Bring pants for high grass.

Very easy to find, and pictures can't compare to seeing this place in person. It's a little muddy for the first part of the trail if you park at the cul-de-sac (depending on time of year). The views are beautiful and you can see the seals laying on a rock island.

My daughter and I walked this trail this afternoon with our Labrador retriever.  It is a gem. 

It is rough and wet in spots   However we have had a very wet spring so far this year.

It was arguably the nicest day we have had in 2019 thus far and today is a Sunday.  Hardly anyone was there!  

The three of us enjoyed the moderately difficult hike, the lack of flies, the low number of people and the gorgeous views.

A lovely little hike to beautiful Prospect.  But beware if it has rained recently, it is very very boggy on the trail so wear appropriate footwear. Rocky underfoot as well. Alternatively, tide permitting you could walk over the rocks which woukd make easier going if boggy. I parked at Hages Lane turning circle walked to Prospect 4.4km and looped back 4.7km along the road as i was pushed for time and tramping back across the bogs is time consuming watching where you put your feet. It is windy on this coastline when the mist is in so wrap up in layers. Also spotted some birds and ducks along the way.

Beautiful coastal hike. Winds off the ocean keep things cool so dress accordingly. We did not encounter any other hikers this time of year. The exposed trail was wind swept with snow built up in crevices (sometimes knee deep). Exceptional scenery. Be prepared and bring water and food. There was some water we had to navigate as streams were flowing from melt water and rain. We hiked from Prospect Village along the coastal trail and looped back on the road to our truck. Total distance covered was 8.8km.

I lived in Prospect Village for years and just love the area. It's just beautiful in all seasons. Hiking is especially pleasant in summer. The trail is often cool due to wind off the water and fog. Layers are highly recommended,as well as sunblock and a good tied on hat...wind and sun can be strong. Getting close to the water can be dangerous. Be wary of waves and dark, slippy rocks. The tide can come in quickly. Beautiful spot to visit.
Great views. Suggest to take two vehicles and park at each end so you don’t have to double back.

Absolutely gorgeous views but you need to watch your feet as the trail can be rocky or soft. Very easy to twist an ankle. And yes sometimes it can be tricky to find the path. This is NOT private land. It’s a conservation area and the trail is maintained. Wonderful rocky points to climb and sit. Saw people fishing off them. Beautiful spots to watch the sunset.  No services and there’s no easy way to return to your car.  So plan to hike back. I went three times during my week in the area. A hidden gem b

Great trail for hikers of all levels. The end of the trail is a beautiful lookout and is spectacular to see, especially for somewhere so close to the city. Make sure to keep to the left when you start out on the trail as it can be easy to get off the main trail veering ever so slightly right and you’ll get into some thick brush.
Great hike, beautiful views. Recommend good hiking boots if you want to explore too far the terrain is very rocky.
the prospect high head trail is  on private property please do not use it and please pass the word to go somewhere else
Nice trail good work for trail running. Nice diverse forest on the way up and then more open grassy spots up top. Coastal lookout of shore island and Cabot trail was nice.
Très belle randonnée peu fréquenté, vues époustouflantes. Un joyau très bien gardé.

Great hike and spectacular views! Loved the climb up walking on the brook, definitely bears and moose around, didn't see any but lots of evidence. So worth the trip and highly recommend if the weather is clear
great hike and views. watch out for bear poop.

There are 2 trails heads by the National Park Information Centre. As soon as you turn on the road to the info centre, if you look left, you’ll see a large sign. If you are behind the info centre by the Adirondack chairs, look across the road and you will see it. 
We took the other one. Park at the top of the parking lot away from the info centre and walk straight past the campground for a few minutes. 
This is a very strenuous hike. I recommend counter clockwise. The first 20 minutes is an unrelenting steep incline, but the other way is even harder. You do get nice views of the mountain range on your right. Once you get up that initial kilometre or so, it’s more sane with a mix of up & down with a lovely, babbling brook beside you. Then the last kilometre or so is up, up and up to the top. You’ll know when you’re at the top when the trees thin out and you see an eagle or two. You come around the turn and start heading along the other side of the trail but it is still a little way before you get to the red Adirondack chair. There’s the chair and a bench to rest and take in the great views. And there’s an even better view when you get back on the main trail. Then a little ways down, they’ve built a deck with some great views. 
The walk down is steep and your thighs will be burning. Bring plenty of water. They sell it at the info centre.

Great hike.  Clockwise had quite the climb but worth it.  3 to 4 km of climbing.  Hiking with 2 dogs so glad we brought a lot of water as no water sources on the way up.  Near the top were wild blueberries so stopped to pick.  The descent was great along the creek and the dogs loved the water.
Wide trail. Really rocky. Great views half way through. Lots of jagged and loose rocks on the way down.
Great trail. The views from the look out points are worth it!
Excellent.
Very beautiful and easy going
Not an easy hike but had nice views! First few kilometres are the most difficult.
The Acadian is steep trail with awesome views and is well worth the struggle
Beehives trail is very difficult and danger!
Third time here, beautiful as always! A little easier if you go counter clockwise but just as pretty no matter which way you go!

We loved this trail! Did last weekend after a lot of rain. The coastal side was pretty clear, not much snow. The interior side along the Brook was quite snowy in parts. Really beautiful views, good incline. Was very windy that day, we did the coastal side first so the wind was at our backs and it was lovely. Lots of downed trees on the coastal side, and LOTS of moose poop, and tracks. Both really fresh. At times we thought for sure we were following him. Didn’t see one unfortunately, but he was definitely around!

Beauty day to be out. Bring snowshoes. Path isn’t marked very well and we had to break trail so the map helped when we were unsure. Follow the river and you should be alright. Stick to the right so you come down with the views. Lots of Moose poop and hair but no Moose sightings! Maybe next time.

Really great trail to gain appreciation for the rugged beauty of the Highlands.  I was snowshoeing and the trail was suitable. Less travelled and not many trail markers on the eastern loop (back side) so I did loose the trail for a bit.   Which makes it fun!  I followed a fresh moose track (seriously fresh) through the snow and she seemed to lead me back to the trail. Thanks moose!
Beautiful!
Amazing hike.

Go left at beginning fork as you will be rewarded with the views. Great and quiet trail. Saw an easy dozen snakes sunning on the way up. Coming down through the brook-side in the Acadian forest is an emerald green mossy change from the sunny uphill hike in through some Boreal.
Amazing loop, shaded on the way up.. amazing views on the way down. I recommend going up on the right side and looping back to get the views.

Great trail with a lot of elevation changes and views. 

Did it clockwise and saw the most beautiful view of Cheticamp and the ocean from the top of the mountain. Coming back you hike along a heavily shaded river.

Great trail with two very different forests/fauna that you’ll encounter. Definitely recommend clockwise! I have hiked this trail two other times, both times completing it counter-clockwise, and now that I’ve done it clockwise, I can’t imagine why we ever did it the other way! 
The way up, there are a few steepish hills, but nothing too challenging for someone with average to good cardio fitness (hills aren’t my forte!). Also on the way up, you will encounter SO much moose scat and a few spots of bear scat. I actually did this hike alone this time, and I admit, I was a little nervous. There are many berry patches and open bushy areas on the ascent, that I imagine would be pure heaven for bears. But I didn’t see any think more animated than a squirrel with a leaf in his mouth, peering at me in fascination, from behind a tree trunk. It could be I was the only person he saw, as there was NO ONE else on the trail with me the entire time. It was eerily quiet- other than my loud singing and yogi bear calls, to ward off furry company.
The view was uninspiring, ONLY because it was foggy - not the trail’s fault - my bad for picking a foggy day. Other times that I have done this trail, the views are out of this world - so I do recommend going on a cool, clear day, if you are looking for the best vistas. 
The entire way down, you will feel as if you are stepping through a rain forest but without the humidity, and the stream at your side is so zen-like. Something out of a movie, truly. It looks so different than the trail on the way up - much greener and more lush - like completely different trails that have been merged. A few bridge planks are a bit slippery, so watch your footing, and there’s only one muddy area to traverse. So very easy in that sense.
Great hike, overall! But I highly recommend having a hiking buddy for this one, just for safety sake. Also cell phone service is there almost all the time, but there are a few quick spots where you’ll have no service. Walk a few steps and it will return. Just be aware.

Absolutely beautiful - including all the lookouts, my Fitbit actually calculated around 11 kms; however, the entire hike only took us about 2.5 hours. Very few breaks - just to catch our breath and keep going! I second the reviews that say to do this in clockwise motion, as you’ll appreciate the shade of the latter half. :)

We saw so many moose droppings we thought we might actually see a moose! Great hike. We went clockwise and would recommend doing it that way. It was hot and buggy going up, though coastal views were beautiful. Coming down along the water was so nice and cool. Fewer bugs and lush, beautiful landscape.
This hike is on the difficult side and is hard on your feet. Good, comfortable shoes should be worn. It took about 3.5 hours to complete with all look offs and breaks included.

Hiked 06/2020. I'd say path conditions were roughly the same as the Franey trail in terms of uphill walking difficulty and the changes from rocky-grass-gravel. Lookouts are gorgeous but some of the signs were down so we just went down the little paths

Hiked 11/4/19. Great trail. It provides a variety of terrain and views: birch forests, areas of dense fir trees, tranquil mossy rock stream, followed by wind battered barren trees and grass trail with great overlooks of the gulf, We hiked counterclockwise late in the day, which created wonderful light for the overlook portion. We finished in just over 2 hours, hiking at a rapid pace to beat the dark. We saw woodpeckers and chipmunks, not a single other person at this late point in the season.

One of the better trails in the National Park area of Cape Breton for sure. The west side of the loop is where you’ll see great views of the Cheticamp area and a number of scenic lookouts, while the east side takes you along a gentle brook in a more wooded setting. Pick which order you think you’d like to see it in, or you can do an out and back of the west side if all you want is views. I went with the woods first (counterclockwise) and it seemed like the way up the hill may have been a bit less steep that way, although either way is a gradual climb and isn’t anything super strenuous, and either way the views are worth it.
Challenging incline and superb views. We saw 2 moose at the very top - very very worth it. On the way down we followed the river back to the carpark. One of our favourite hikes in Cape Breton.

We loved this hike, we went clockwise although it seemed most people went counter, we enjoyed it very much. The look offs were amazing and the trail that follows the river was challenging and enjoyable.
Very nice hike and quite a good workout. Lots of different sceneries, likes many different hikes all bundled into one.

Skill level: Intro/Beginner
Difficulty: 7.6/10
Done in Early July
Enjoyed it thoroughly. We did the hike by going up the mountain (so you get peeks of the glorious view as you climb upwards) and then finished going by the brook. We preferred it that was as it was relaxing coming down. The day we went winds were at least 80km/hr so be weary of that. It was a stunning hike and one of our favs at Cabot Trail
The trail is beautiful!  Unfortunately the day we went was very rainy and foggy so the reward at the top was non existent.
it's a hard hike, but the view is worth it :)

Nous avons fait la randonnée en sens inverse de ce qui est proposé, c'est à dire en montant du côté où il n'y a pas de points de vues et en redescendant du côté des points de vues. Ce fut vraiment un bon choix à mon avis puisque presque tout le long de la montée, on longe une petite rivière et on marche au son de ses petites cascades. C'était rafraîchissant.
Fun little 2 hour hike. Well worth a quick stop if driving by while doing the Cabot Trail.
Belle vue à mi-parcour

Loved this trail! Hiked it just before sunset. The views were incredible and the terrain was not too challenging. Pretty magical place overall. We went up near the brook and down the other side. The trail is well marked. Hiked this much more quickly than expected but are experienced hikers. There is an outhouse part of the way up which is a bonus.

Beautiful views, pretty low traffic on a Tuesday afternoon. As others have said, the south face (left hand trail) is definitely easier going. We took the south face down and saw a moose antler.  You can get a kids activity guide (similar to the US Jr. Ranger program) at the visitor center.
Great trail. Saw a moose. No bears. Diverse views and foliage!
This is just an amazing hike! The trail is very pretty and the views are breathtaking! And its not a really hard trail! I’ve worked more for less!

Have done this twice and loved it. Not for the inexperienced. Great views at the top, a lovely stream on one side, and nice scenery all along the way. Keep kids and dogs close as some parts are very narrow with a steep and dangerous drop off.

This was a beautiful hike with stunning views. All uphill if you keep to the left. If you go right, it’s easier going but you will punish your knees on the decent. If you’re an occasional hiker this trail isn’t for you. 
Again, loved every step. 
Note. Trail ended up at 10.9km all said and done. 
Loved it!

A great trail!  We started up on the western trail, which is a little steeper.  But completely doable.  Of course we saw tons of other hikers, but we had a number of nice chats when we stopped to rest, usually at the scenic overlooks.  We were able to see all the destruction caused by the moose, as well as the very different areas of the forrest.  We very much enjoyed the views of the coast, and the stroll along the creek.
Did the full loop but AllTrails did not record the path accurately.  Health app recorded 8.7km for this one.

Take a left when u ascend. This section of the trail is gravel and dirt with benches along the way and a number of excellent look out points. The last two look outs have the best view of Chéticamp village and the Island. U can choose to go back down the same way or do the loop. If u do the loop, be mindful the conditions of the interior trail is rocky and many sections also muddy because it runs along a brook. U will see a number of small waterfalls. We saw a large black bear on our way up. He was on the trail and we observed him from a distance and waited for him to move out before continued.
Gorgeous! Challenging to get up the mountain, but definitely worth the hike!
Personally, we loved the variety of this trail.
Great views, and a thrilling ascent. I wish I was back there.
Amazing view from lookouts
Great early fall walk

beautiful views!!  you can make the hike longer if you add the side trails. we saw hikers of all levels on this trail however be footing and mud can be tricky at times. go on a weekday or early if on a weekend because parking can get busy
Absolutely stunning views. The trail is not marked well - you can pick your path, which we considered great.
interpretive/free form and so pretty!
Radical
excellent trail.
Foggy and windy but still perfect if you love to be near the ocean.
Very scenic and many unmarked paths along the coast, low lying ares are quite wet and muddy.

Trail itself was great both trails. Beautiful views.  Alot of dog shit bags along the bath though. Well better in a bad then on your foot I guess. Also first time ever I found tics. But it's the season.

This trail was beautiful, well marked, easy to find and had lots of different terrain. whether it's rocky, grassy, bushy, or even more woodsy. lovely views and lots of space to walk around without meeting up with anyone.
Always my favourite and worth the trek—rain or shine, no matter what season.
Great for rock hopping, can get close to the water and get great exercise! Gorgeous all seasons.
Beautiful. Heaven on earth.

The main trail is easy to see, but is quite short. This location is perfect for those who like to get off the beaten path. We roamed around for about 2 hours (4km) on rock, in mud, over limbs and up and down! The views were amazing and we easily could have spent the day there! (It was extremely windy and the waves were huge!) No strollers, would be difficult with a baby/ child carrier on, no small children in my opinion for anything but the main path. Loved it and will be taking family and friends for sure!
Fairly short trail, a little marshy in some areas but overall in good condition. Stunning views!
Decent hike - unclear trails and quite a few mushy spots but worth the view if you’re out Peggy’s Cove area
Pretty marshy if you’re going after a big rain, but beautiful and engaging.
Stunning!
Great walk and very much a choose your own adventure! Some great views of the sea all the way round
Great hike! Tons of sights to see and paths to explore. There didn’t seem to be one way but instead, many!
One of my favourites. Is a bit of a “choose your own adventure” in terms of navigating the trail, but I like that. Love walking on the big rocks and beautiful views of the ocean.
Cool rocks and beautiful ocean views, but confusing to navigate.
Should have picked a less windy day and different shoes - can’t wait to go back!
Must visit!

First time on the trail and it is a bit confusing, so I wandered around quite a bit but it was all lovely. some fun scrambling if you take side paths. Polly cove and the surrounding tide pools are wonderful at low tide.
Perfect destination when you want coastal views and do not have a lot of time. Popular one too!
Good location for kids, beautifu Peggy's-esque open ocean and granite boulder landscape. High traffic. Can be colder with wind, bring a windbreaker.

It’s a beautiful hike with great scenery but. Little confusing to navigate. No trail markers at all. The path is easy to see most of the time but we did go down a couple of wrong paths and scratched our heads a few times. There are two trailheads off the parking lot. One leads to the long trail and the following the other you can get to the high ground with the picnic table and scenic views in about 15-20 minutes.
Amazing trail! My 5 year old son is on his way to becoming an expert hiker. He was thrilled with this trail, and only needed some assistance.
Awesome trail with fabulous ocean views
dead whale. wet trail.

The first part is a well-traveled private road: walkers welcome, but respect the homeowner’s privacy.

The second part is a very challenging trail through puddles, rocks, roots, and bushes. The ocean view is nice, and the trail does indeed exist, but it’s not accomodating. There’s also a rope closing off the trail where I stopped - whether it’s a warning, a limit, or a prank is outside my knowledge.

Started by the beach - great trail. Easy to follow the blue painted dots. It became very hard to follow after about 4-5k. Would have been lost without the app. The last 3-4 k was very muddy in places and very very overgrown. The last photo shows what the trail looked like near the end. Good hike just a little uncertain at times as to where to go.
Beautiful, but very outgrown, especially the last 25%.

first part of the trail was well marked,
 but the back trail, well thank God for All Trails or I wouldn't have found the trail at times.  Very overgrow and quite muddy.

do the trail counter clockwise so you get the views and the wind at the last half of the hike.   I loved loved this hike. it had everything in it.  my husband said it's a 3 start trail because of the mud and narrow parts on the west part. I thought that was fun.

Beautiful views, definitely would recommend going out and back starting from the parking lot (trail near the beach/bathrooms) instead of the loop. The last 3-4km coming back down the loop (clockwise) was muddy, overgrown in spots and buggy, mostly in the woods so not much to see anyway. Otherwise a nice not too difficult hike, and great views. Although the description here says there’s a waterfall but I didn’t see one and can’t really imagine where one would be on the trail.

muddy and rocky at times. 1st half was well marked and stunning views. 2nd half was rough in parts of the trail on the cliff were slippery and sections eroded with no markers. it was easy to get lost.

I love this trail but it is really wet and muddy in a lot of places. If you’re hiking be ready to get wet. Running same thing. Crossing some wet spots what seem to be good foot holds only turn out to be wet shoe traps. Can’t wait for it to dry a bit.

The trail was very scenic, took a lot of cool photos of the coastline along the east side. The ground was very wet but I was wearing waterproof hiking shoes which helped a lot. I attempted the west side on the return and ended up turning around and coming back the east side, it was kind of bushy and I wasn’t into it.

It had beautiful scenery all along the trail. There was at times were did the trail go due to sections not used so much or I did not see as many markings on the west side. I had clock 12kms back to the parking lot with doing all along the coast trail.
Lots of horse flies today on back part of trail

Do not recommend anyone taking the spine trail back to the parking lot…. It is extremely wet/soggy at this point in time with potentially 1 ft of water and no alternative areas to use. Stick to the shoreline.

Going clockwise from parking lot the first 6.5 km is amazing. Great views and not overly technical. Last 3.5 km is just in tree line along coast and you are fighting mud bogs the whole way which slows you down and is not quite as fun. Overall a great hike.

Beautiful trail however be prepared if you do the entire loop that is is muddy and a bit tricky to find the trail when going from coastline into the wooded trail. The second part (when going clockwise) was the muddiest. If you want to avoid big mud puddles, especially with a dog, then simply do this trail out and back from the point as it was in much better shape than the last part on the west side.
Really beautiful trail, the trail markings end about halfway through but it’s fairly easy to navigate.  Extremely muddy in places even on a dry day.
Great trail with fantastic views. Very easy to follow. A bit boggy in spots, good shoes recommended

Gorgeous views and hike! muddy this time of the year, and have to follow spray painted rocks at some points to stay on trail. Over all loved it! Took us 3 hours to do the whole loop and will definitely do it again!
Definitely a relaxing hike for the first half - completing the loop was an accomplishment but I wouldn't do it again, would just stick to the trail from the beach to the Point.
Very nice hike fairly easy to navigate although the second half of the loop isn’t blazed.

It took 2.5 hours for thr two of us to walk this trail. We loved the coastal views, variety of ecological conditions and the beauty of being in nature. A fellow hiker pointed out a smooth green snake that was the most exquisite shade of green and apparently quite rare. Sadly I did get a nasty blister but it didn't spoil the hike.

One of my favourite trails. Very muddy and messy this time of year. Some parts of the trail are hard to find if you do the whole loop and aren’t using a map. Beautiful trail but so much garbage along the interior and coastal parts of the trail where there isn’t much traffic. If that’s something you care about, I’d recommend bringing in a couple of garbage bags and taking some out with you. Just took out a couple of bags today and will bring more next time.
Muddy in spots but great once you get past the beach and away from the crowds.
Great hike, Some muddy patches so keep that in mind. Great views and wasn’t packed with people (great with the current covid numbers)
Super muddy on the interior trail sections so wear proper footwear.  Otherwise a great hike

Trail is marked pretty clearly with some light blue spray paint on the rocks. A few dead end trails break off the main trail and it became a bit harder to follow just before reaching east pennant. 

Overall a really great trail. Dress for the conditions!
Beautiful ocean views. Big crashing waves. Muddy and fun overall!

Front half (coming from Crystal Crescent Provincial Park) is great. There are blue spray paint markings on rocks to follow. The back half is much less marked, so I ended up turning around and backtracking. 

There are some challenging sections where poles would’ve been useful, but I did fine without them.
Fantastic Day!

Beautiful but challenging hike. There were tons of boggy spots due to recent rain and snow melt, so good hiking boots are a must. Lots of washed out areas on the west side of the trail so be careful. We did the trail counterclockwise and we’re glad we got the terrible wet boggy areas on the central and western parts of the loop over with early, or else it would have been a yucky way to end the hike. Lots of stunning views - would hike again. If you don’t have all day then stick to the eastern trails, the best views are there.
Trail was good, although there were times it was hard to follow. Some beautiful views along the way. Took longer than expected but worth it.
great trail, easy to follow with great ocean views. good foot wear is needed.
Happy we went counter clockwise and that we did it in winter. The small trails would be tight with all the shrubs. Beautiful views !!!

A bit of a challenging hike. Took us longer than expected. Some beautiful views along the way and the sound of the waves was soothing. Given the time of year with a lot of snow having melted, it was quite muddy in some spots. Decent hiking boots are important. The app helped keep us on track. Not well marked in some places. Blue dots painted on many rocks along first half of trail (we went counter clockwise). If you’re up for a good (but not easy!) hike and have hours to kill, this is a good one! Note: we parked close to the locked gate, along the road where there are obvious “no parking” signs and we did get a ticket. It’s unfortunate that so many trail parking lots are closed off at this time of year.
Beautiful trail! We loved it. However there are a few sections where we had to figure out where the trail was. We went on February 5 and it was very muddy as we had a lot of rain and a few warm days.
Trail was very difficult to follow as it comes out of the woods on the east side. The snow has blown over the trail and made large snow drifts

Wonderful hike. Great views. We did the hike clockwise. Very clearly marked until about 7-8k along. At that point, we could not see how to continue and there were no markers. It was very wet so I guess the trail was covered with water? We backtracked and started to head back the way we came. We ended up doing the trail that is up from the water and it is WET right now.  I definitely recommend this hike but would not do the in-land trail.  Keep ocean side.

I did the trail counter-clockwise Nov 22, 2020. It was a very enjoyable experience at a few degrees above freezing. Quite different temperatures whether in the trees or out on the rocks in the wind. Some very rugged rock hopping and some muddy and boggy areas also. Very enjoyable overall.
Beautiful nearly every step of the way. A little tricky when water is on the trail, but nothing strenuous.
Same as everyone else has said about conditions!! Amazing views throughout definitely one I will do again

Good hike! Will echo a couple of the comments below with the gorgeous views, especially on the east side. The west side of the trail is not as well marked and I did find myself off it a couple of times. Because it’s along the coast it was easy to get back on. Muddy areas so boots are best, and pants for sure, especially for the last stretch across back to the parking lot! Also the gate is now closed for the season so you need to park close to the road and walk in and through the parking lot to access the trail.
Good trail, the west slide of the loop was very muddy and over grown and not well marked. Very beautiful though and the beach is a bonus!!!

Easy hike, gorgeous ocean views. Took me 3 hours including a long lunch stop. Went at 8:30 on a Saturday morning and had the trail to myself. Only one bit of the path was a little washed out but I found the trail again without too much trouble.
Nice easy run. Enjoy doing this one when I don’t feel like a long run or after I’ve done the Bluff a couple of days in a row.

Beautiful hike! So many spots where it just opens up and the views are amazing. 

Overgrown in a lot of spots. Thank god I was wearing pants or my legs would be pretty torn up. App was needed to navigate some of the trails as they are overgrown and there are some places that look like trail that are not. 

Barely saw any other people. Very cool to stand on the rocks and hear the water and then keep walking to the utter silence of the woods. Well worth the overgrown parts!
Great trail!  Some amazing views!  Definitely needed the app for navigation!
Wet in the usual spots after the rain.
Great easy run along the coast. Wet in some spots near the end. But not major.

I hiked counter clockwise, as a lot of people suggested below. Really enjoyed the first half of the hike, mixture of woods and coastal. Saw very few people on a Friday afternoon, only big crowds once I reached the beach. Trail is overgrown, wet and soggy at some places.

Whoa! I had no idea this great adventure was only mere steps past the nude beach! 

Walked this trail last month and loved it! Beautiful coastal views similar to Taylor Head and Pollys Cove. I found the last half of the trail to be a bit sketchy (I went clockwise) because it’s a bit grown in and not well marked but it was still fun. 

Near the last bit in the open fields I ran into a hawk mama who was not very excited about me being there. She chased and swooped for a little bit- I made sure to face her direction, yell, and put my backpack above my head and it was fine. Thinking she must of had some fresh lil babies! 

Also on the last half my gps kept telling me I was in Lunenburg? If this happens don’t worry, you haven’t mysteriously been transported to Lunenburg... not that I thought that or anything... 


Also! I encourage you to look up the Indigenous histories and presents of the land you’re hiking on. Think about what it means as settlers to use this unceded Mi’kmaq land for pleasure.

A great trail. Recommend going anti clockwise so that you go through the ever so slightly overgrown and humid section first, and cool off with the sea breeze and views along the second half. 

Well but subtly marked along the length of the trail. The map on here is reliable too.

Some hopping between rocks is necessary, and a few patches will be quite muddy outside of summer.
Great trail.  Beautiful views of the ocean, large open fields.   Did this mid summer and still muddy spots but manageable.
Great trail! Single track not too technical for trail running. But you need to pay attention to the trail ... ground trail is easy to follow but quite overgrown with ferns and such at eye level.
Unreal trail and views. Probably one of the best coastal trails in HRM. Follow the blue marks on the ground to stay on the trail. Some overgrown and muddy spots.

Started going cross country from beach and hiking counterclockwise. That was a good decision. Some overgrown areas. Wear long pants if hiking the complete loop. Had some technical difficulty with recording but it’s about 10k in total. Still a bit muddy in spots. Is the seal rock just nature’s art?! Amazing! Not many bugs at all and it was a humid drizzly day. A real gem of a trail in NS.

Hiked the East Pennant Point trail today. (July 19) 10.5km, 20300 steps in 4 hours. We started at the green dot at the top and took screen shot when 1/2 way (blue dot). Great trail, wet in places, watch the footing and roots, few deer flies other then that no bugs, so this is a good time of year to walk it. Great views. Places to sit and enjoy the views. I would suggest walking the top barren woods across to the bay part first because it may be a hot run and very tiring at the end. 
Expect some nudity in place to in passerby’s as you getting closer to the third beach.

The hike was pretty awesome in the beginning. Got nice views and Fresh ocean breeze. But half of the trail is not well maintained and got really narrow overgrown paths. Remember to take mosquito repellent cream and water

Completed this hike today starting from the beach end to the point and up the far side of the point and through the woods/barrens back to the parking lot.

The trail past the beaches and to the point is fairly well marked but it is so open that it is impossible to get lost. Beautiful scenic ocean views along the way. It is fairly busy as the trail to this point is not difficult so it is an attraction for those who are not hardcore hikers. Most of them however, hike to the point and turn around and return the way they came.

Continuing past the point the crowd thins out immensely. About half of the far side is similar to the hike to the point. The trail is not marked as well but it is so open that you cannot get lost. There are several spots where high tide could create an issue with a dry passage. 

The second half of the far side winds into the woods along the shore peaking out once in a while to the ocean shoreline but really never goes far into the woods. This leg of the trail is much more challenging with rocks, roots and mud. The trail is not marked but is very obvious so again getting lost is not a worry. 

The last bit of the backside cuts straight accross the point back to the parking lots. Half of this is through the woods and half of it is through barren plains. Low bushes with spots of pine trees poking up. 

I would recommend sturdy and waterproof boots with ankle support, especially if you plan to complete the loop. The backside is where these are needed in particular. 

Over all its a great hike with beautiful views. I completed it in roughly 2.5 hours and that was with several rest/snack stops.

Trail was great, especially for this time of year. Definitely some mud to run into that may slow ya down but easy to get around. Great time overall. 

Ps. Be careful with off leash dogs. Was warned of porcupines.
Beautiful views! very muddy & wet portions of the trail. Expect to throw sneakers in the wash.
Great trail. Bit muddy. I started counterclockwise which i preferred as first 1k of trail is meh.
Very wet and muddy but not impassible doing the loop, and no flies!
Awesome hike around the point then up to army shack
One of my most favourite trails. Easily navigated with sweeping ocean views and sounds of waves crashing the entire way. Enjoy some beach time when done!! Highly recommend.
Worst trial.

Gorgeous trail, but as others have said, the last portion of the trail is very challenging in terms of getting lost due to overgrowth, lack of markings and lack of trail maintenance. Best time to hike this one is in the spring before everything blooms and obstructs the view of the trail. First time I did this trail in the summer I had to do a lot of bushwacking. In the spring I didn't get lost at all. Definitely a worthwhile trail with gorgeous views.
Great hike! Beautiful colours. A few downed trees in the way and a lot of muck in certain sections.
Trail is hard to follow, must get out by dark
Beautiful first half. Back half hard to follow and swampy in places. Lots of wild blueberry.
This is a beautiful trail.  However the back half of the trail is muddy and not well maintained.  Recommend turning back at the marsh section.   Back half is poorly marked as well.
A bit more challenging then I anticipated. But a fantastic hike.  Trail tough to follow at times. App kept me on route.  A must do again!

lovely first half starting from the public beach followed the spray painted blue rocks, got about 6km down and found the rock with a smiley....should have been a sign to turn around! the path pretty much disappears for 2km and I was scambling around on rocks right on the water, pretty dangerous. for sure wear long pants and boots with ankle support.

Absolutely Loved this trail! We went August 3rd, 2019 as a family, two boys 7 and 10 and my hubby. Took us about 4 hours stopping for lunch, pictures and a few water breaks. There weren’t  really much muddy spots because of the dry weather a few grown in spots, we all wore shorts and we’re fine. Such a piece of paradise!

Visited on July 31st 2019. Had no trouble staying on the path until about half way around the loop, couldn't find the trail and doubled back. We went clockwise, starting at the beach and past the nude beach! It was foggy but beautiful scenery and ocean mist/spray along the way. Didnt find it too boggy or wet as it's been very hot with little rain lately. My 6 month old puppy had no trouble on our route. Bring your bathing suit for a swim at Crystal Crescent Beach afterwards!
Great trail. Loved every minute of it. Great views. Good photo opportunity. Some parts could be muddy. A must visit when in the area.
Beautiful trail with lots of interesting rock formations and stunning ocean views. Still some mud and bog but drying up a bit with the lovely weather.

if you are traveling and do not have access to spare hiking shoes/boots i do not recommend doing the western half of the loop... its too wet and muddy... 
i followed the trail clockwise, going along the eastern shoreline...when i got to the southern most part i thought to myself "maybe i should just double back."   this trail is a spectacular out and back trail... would have been a 5 if id chosen to do that but alas i chose to do the loop...the western half was "meh"... in comparison...

Amazing views along the coast. Trail was very muddy and there was a small stream we had to cross, so be prepared to get your shoes wet. Make sure to keep your dog on a leash; I spotted some porcupines right by the trail.

I do not recommend completing the loop unless you’re looking to get wet and muddy. Stay on the ocean side as the in land portion of the trail is extremely muddy at this time. Trail is well marked for the most part

I would recommend this trail to hikers of all ages especially those looking for dog friendly trails. It starts off with a gravel trail that strings along the coastline. The path turns into a semi wooded semi bluff trail around the point. The views are breathtaking and the sound of the ocean brings a rhythmic calm to the hike. It’s a good idea to bring extra socks and shoes for the drive home. There are quite a few spots along the trail that are very wet and muddy. Also along the hike there are thorny bushes, might be a good idea to wear long pants if it isn’t too hot out. I wore capris and I walked away with a dozen scratches on my calves. It was super helpful to have the blue spray painted markers to help keep you on the right path. All in all a beautiful hike, I will definitely visit again!
Loved it, muddy at times bit I picked a rainy day so no complaints. Beautiful views, trail and amazing energy
Nice hike around the point and back on the pennant harbor side. Few bouys washed up on the shore !

First half ( beach side) is well marked with blue paint. Transition to the second part of the trail was hard to find. Lots of wet parts on the trail, definitely wear hiking boots, not meant for sneakers. Great view of the ocean and beautiful beaches.
Hiked south along the Pennant Harbour side to Pennant Point, returned north across the centre of the peninsula.
Awesome hike. Views were spectacular!
Really ended hike at start point at 3.5 hours...just forgot to stop recording.

A fun trail with nice views. Keep to the spray painted blue markers to find the trail for most of the way. Be prepared for anything though: mud, rocks, boulders, bogs, overgrown trails...and nudists :/ 
Took me just under 4 hours with a couple stops.

Fantastic views on this trail for the most part. It took me 4.5 hours to complete the whole trail. For last 1 hour or so there was a lot of bushwacking involved and there was some mud. Despite that I would definitely recommend checking out this trail.
Just walked to the point and back - absolutely spectacular!
Kniiy
Difficult to find some paths. I made a route of my own along paths. I enjoyed it.
Good trail. I’ll be back again.

Great trail. If you start on the beach someone has spray painted blue squares to help guide you to the point. After the point those squares are gone and it can be hard to find the trail at times and may require some bushwacking. 
Phenomenal coastal views and if you go past the point not many people do so you'll enjoy some solitude. Definitely on the top hikes list.
Nice scenery and a great trail.  Only loses a star because the marking of the route is not always clear so someone might get easily lost.  Great fun and definitely recommend!
Took about 4 hours to complete 10km hike.  My favorite trial☺️

Nice trail along a spectacular seashore. Soggy at times but nothing one cannot navigate around. The part that overlaps with the Crystal Crescent beach trail is easier to follow and equally beautiful. To avoid overgrowth and sogginess go to the tip of the peninsula and back. Amazing views ...highly recommended.
Very nice hike though easy to get turned around the trail is not marked in a lot of places.

Wish I had read the other reviewers comments prior to leaving on this trip as I struggled to find a route at the tip. 

This trail would be much easier to travel in a counter clockwise direction... the trail markers are sporadic blue dots painted on rocks, but are very difficult to spot travelling clockwise.

All in all was a lovely hike, despite the bog being incredibly wet from the rain. I will be trying this one again in the future!

Great loop trail with fantastic atlantic coastal scenery. Trail can become a bit absent in a couple parts, one notably by the large salt water pond near the tip, in which you'll pick up the trail again on the other side by either traversing the rocks on the ocean side or thru the tall grass on the other side of the pond, which could be a bit wet depending on the season. Also if you're doing the trail CCW, the trailhead is not marked with anything but a couple rocks just before it so this is where a previous gps track might help.
Great stroll, gorgeous view and great for children and elderly! Barely anybody there in September!
Absolutely gorgeous! The trails were well maintained, got some amazing pictures, and even saw 2 moose!

Really easy to do! It's more like a walk. Once you reach the point where it is a loop, the left side brings you faster to the main viewpoint. Once you get there, there's a lot of stairs down to be closer to the main view.

More of a long walk rather than a hike. It is a really popular trail so if you are looking for peace and quiet this is not the trail for you. Sad to see lots of people going off the boardwalk when lots of signs saying not to do so. Someone also brought their dog when there are lots of posted signs at the trailhead saying dogs not allowed. Great view at the top but I’m not sure if it’s any different from what I’ve already seen from the lookoffs or from other hikes. Would still recommend.
Beauty trail.  Nice easy walk with unbeatable views.  Busy trail but everyone is very respectful.  A must do when visiting Cabot Trail
Very well maintained trail. Highly trafficked trail

Great trail, that is relatively flat and shaded in some parts. A few lookouts and then the boardwalk at the end that overlooks the famous Cabot Trail. There were washrooms in the parking lot and half way through the trail. Didn’t see any wildlife and passed probably over 100 people just on my way in and the same going back. There were Parks Canada employees in the parking lot writing tickets for no/expired passes - make sure you have a pass or you will have to go to the kiosk to buy one anyways, or be billed $150 at the end of the season. This is a trail you absolutely must do if you’re on the island.

We did the loop counter clockwise. You aren’t missing much if you do the direct hike, left at the fork, to the view, but we enjoyed the full loop. Perfect for all ages… it’s more of a stroll than a hike.

Super easy trail. Very maintained. Do not bring your dog, as pet owners were being turned away. I found it quite busy, but with the views you are faced with, I can see why. I recommend for all ages. "It's a walk in the park".
Great walk/hike to the look off spot. The best views of coastal Cape Breton we saw all trip. Lots of stairs down and up : ) A “must do” trail if you’re in the area. And we saw a moose and it’s baby!
Great trail. Easy to walk, little to no bugs. Bathrooms at both ends. Father-in-law is 85 and we did the return trip in 4 hours.

Easy trail. Well maintained, beautiful views along the way. Easy and level terrain. Beautiful view of the ocean at the end. Outhouses along way. We only had time for the short trail so we made it to the viewing point at 45 minutes (1.5 hours round trip). A grumpy bird (possibly a louse?) wouldn’t let us pass the trail assuming it had babies near by …. We had to jump over it and run hahaha made for a good story/memory of the trail. Will definitely be back and do the large trail next time
The skyline is an every-year kind of trail! It’s busy, but easy enough for the whole family so that should be expected! It’s extra beautiful if you go at sunset!
Done this hike 2 days ago trail is clear from snow. We walked the groomed trail side so I am unsure what the other path may look like.

Snow can be very deep so best with
 skis or snowshoes.
excellent views and a good chance to see a Moose!
Fantastic in the winter. Light snow. A little slippery. Only saw 4-5 other people. Gorgeous views. Very peaceful. One of Cape Breton’s great hikes. Very flat, maintained, gravel trail.
Gravel trail that was easy to navigate. The stairs down to the platform and back up are challenging but worth the view.
Well maintained trail, no roots or rocks to avoid. Boardwalk only starts near the end, the rest is tiny gravel. Great hike as expected!
Don't do it during a windstorm.

Really good views, but REALLY crowded. More of a gentle walk rather than a hike.

The trail map on this app needs updating to reflect that you can do an 8k loop as well as out and back.

Unfortunately, I picked a terrible day to go. 3 degrees, with excess wind, rain and hail. But I think given better weather, it would be amazing. The trail itself is a bit boring, but the views from the boardwalk are worth it! No moose to be seen today

This trail was an easy and gorgeous trail to complete. Came up from the South Shore to check it out, and the view. It was absolutely stunning. I am so glad we did this. The upkeep was beautiful. There are uphill spots but I feel anyone can complete this. (:
Excellent views. Easy to follow

Great easy hike. Trail is a 10/10 for upkeep and maintenance. I have hiked this trail and the loop maybe ten or so times over the years. Very much a favourite. 

Please stay on the trail once you hit the boardwalk. There is a fragile ecosystem underfoot. We all need to respect our surroundings.

We saw a moose!
An easy trail with an epic payoff.
Nothing particularly special about this trail apart from it being featured in the park brochure.
Easy trail, wide and flat with outstanding views at the viewing platforms. Be sure to do the entire loop.

This was a very enjoyable hike. As noted, it is crushed rock and boardwalk so nothing too strenuous but the views at the end of the boardwalk were stunning. And we saw 2 moose! Worth doing the full loop

Had the trail all to ourselves at 7:00am on the Monday of August long weekend. Great trail, mostly crushed rock and some boardwalk. No roots or rocks to stumble over. First 70% of the trail is lots of the same dense fauna undergrowth. Beautiful views at the end of the trail of picturesque cliffs and winding hills.
Super quick and easy if you just go straight to the boardwalk/skyline and back. Parking is usually pretty full but it is well worth the stop. Low effort for massive payoff with the amazing views!
one of the most rewarding views and hikes of my time spent in the highlands.

June 2019. Well kept trail, easy terrain with combination of crushed gravel and beaten grass, last portion is wooden boardwalk and many stairs (fragile vegetation signs to stay on boardwalk), leading to scenic views of Cabot Trail and ocean. Popular and crowded spot all times of day. This return trail is shaded, the loop is not.
Rainy day with high winds but still a great hike!
Great trail! Easy path and walking and a great view at the end. Bring water and snacks! There are outhouses along the way.
Very easy walk along the wide pathways and boardwalks. The coastal view was spectacular and sunset was beautiful.
Gentle hike - gorgeous lookout!
Easy hike. Took the Sunset guided tour. Saw several moose along the way. Beautiful boreal forest. Spectacular view of the sun setting at the boardwalk.

I had read that it was a spectacular trail but didn’t really know why. Very easy, mostly level hike through alpine area with occasional short sections of boardwalks. A pleasant walk until you come to the end. But then from a sort of hidden platform the last few hundred meters is a boardwalk open to the sky and the hills and the sea way down there. On our way back late afternoon we came across a mother moose and her two adolescents feeding by the trail and waited very quietly in a little outlook spur until they wandered by and we continued on. Shortly after that we came across a male moose and made a much hastier retreat to that spur while it trotted by. Unforgettable!
Beaucoup de monde mais cela vaut quand même le coup !
A long walk in the forest in the beginning. But the view in the end is worth it. It’s a great place to watch sunset.
Great trail. Gravel path the entire way. Awesome trail for all abilities with a breathtaking view. This trail is best enjoyed at sunset as it looks west over the ocean.

Nice trail - 4.5 stars.  In good condition.  We did the in and out and not the loop.  The view is good along the way but the last board walk section is what made the trail so famous.  This trail ideally should be done first thing in the morning or right before sunset since it is quite exposed.  Avoid doing it midday in sunny days.  

There is a view on the drive near the trail that actually offers a better view.
Loop is closed, in and out is open. Beautiful views but very very touristy.  The trail itself is very well groomed (with stone and boardwalk), flat and easy.
schöner Trail, wenn auch leider sehr überlaufen. aber dennoch: Es lohnt sich. Teil des Trails ist zurzeit gesperrt.
Part of the loop is closed right now.

Walked this trail late morning and it was so busy! Lots of tourists - not your standard trail interactions (i.e. most people were not very friendly). Nice views. Lots of sun exposure (not a lot of shade). If I were to do it again I would do it in the early morning before the crowds come out or much later in the evening once people have left for the day. Very accessible trail until you reach the end and then there are stairs down. The loop was under construction/maintenance when we were there so it was not possible to walk the loop.

Great short trail suitable for all fitness levels. Gravel slight decline for the majority of the trail until the board walk is reached. Be sure to close the moose gates behind you.

Skippable observation tower about 500 meters away from the boardwalk.
