Went on a Tuesday, mid day, peak season and saw just under 100 people. Trail and scenic walk is large enough to accomadate at least triple that.
Pleasant, varied trail friendly to most ages and fitness.  Many people but not crowded or shopping mall in-the-ways.

Did this trail June 2018, got there for 8am and it was a beautiful, quiet hike.  Got to see a Moose sleeping nearby.  On the way back, which is at a slight incline for most the trail, I was sharing the trail with many, many people headed to the top.  With that said, the view from the top is indescribable and stunning.

I’m a 50+ woman, not totally out of shape.  The trail goes to the boardwalk and back.  The part along the “edge” is closed.  Coming back up the stairs and up the incline almost the entire way back was taxing, but I kept up my pace.  Took me an hour and 40 minutes.

Like rush hour in NYC! The loop section and at least one of the overlooks were closed AND it was super crowded! We turned back after the first overlook which was nice but not super.  The trail itself is pleasant but the crowds felt overwhelming. Yesterday we hiked Acadian Trail - harder climb but much less traffic and stellar views.
Demi boucle fermée. Sentier touristique en gravier. Touristique. Pour la vue sur l’océan seulement.
Easy trail with nice views, we did it in late May last year, a section of the trail was closed and the trail was very crowded which isn't our style.
longue marche mais pas de grosse pente donc facile a faire.la vue est incroyable rendu au bout

WINDY!

The day we went winds clocked 122km/h in town and were estimated at 140-160. 

As a result it was only physically possible to go about 1/3 of the way down the boardwalk. Surprised that the trail was not closed, to be honest.

Incredible views from the point we were able to get to and at the various lookouts along the way.

Partial weight bearing on forearm crutches, this trail  was accessible enough for those with similar mobility: a wide path, no roots or ruts, smooth dirt for the most part and the gentlest of inclines.

We didn’t see moose (though there were lots of tracks), a few garter snakes were basking in the sun on the trail.

Great for a first visit. Have been multiple times; the easy terrain and well maintained trails make it great for any activity level on the loop or the out|back. But after a couple visits you are ready to move on to more exciting hikes, with better views, and less foot traffic.

I liked this trail. It was easy and the views are beautiful. NS has a love hate relationship with moose. They killed them off, brought them back and still want to control where they go. I didn’t see any wildlife, and the walk is easy enough. I don’t think I would do the boardwalk again. It was crowded and can be seen from the top.
As the French say, 'Eh!' Not so grand.
Must do trail.. the view of ocean is like a painting on a canvas.

The iconic trail of the Cape Breton Highlands National Park, The views are great (but they are beatable) and access is easy, great way to feel hike you are a real hiker without actually doing any real hiking. Tthis has, for many true hikers, ruined the trail.  Dogs are strictly not allowed on this trail, but people still bring them and let them shit everywhere, tourists just drop their garbage trailside and trample delicate foliage just to get a better photo.  The trail is overrun all summer.  Off season is better.
The views are unbeatable
Easy hike with beautiful sunsets
stroller friendly until the very last part which is the stairs leads to the outlook. great walk
excellent
Nice walk with a bit of wildlife along the way (moose and “hikers” with flip flops). Nice view at the end with a big descending boardwalk. A bit busy for my liking but a fun trip nonetheless.

The trail is in amazing shape, beautifully manicured and even has a bathroom in the middle.  We were unlucky and happened to be visiting when smoke from the west coast fires created a TON on haze and the sunset was completely blocked out by the haze.  

But...we did see a moose as we returned to the car.  We saw it  just to be east of the fenced in area (to keep out the moose).  I will post a picture.  The moose came way to close (for my liking), we were about 50 feet away as it galloped by, quite a treat!
Der Trail ist einfach zu laufen, nur die letzten Meter über die Stufen sind anstrengend, dafür ist die Aussicht grandios und es sind sehr viele Leute unterwegs
Saw a moose 10 feet away from the high traffic trail but the view at the end is absolutely gorgeous!!
really windy ! amazing views !! the juice is worth the squeeze.

As expected, spectacular views! Trail was an easy stroll. Saw families with strollers and flip flops. Had opportunity to pass through a Moose exclosure...be sure to close the gate behind you. Hiked this trail the day after we hiked the Franey trail. Wanted something easy. It was.
Absolutely stunning view! And it’s totally worth it to go off trail near the end to get to the point! Just be careful if it’s windy! Also saw a moose at the beginning of the trail!

The views to difficulty ratio on this hike is insane; for the amount of work you do, the views at the end are def worth it. The boardwalk at the end really makes you feel like you are part of the land scape. Would recommended
The view is something you cannot explain or understand from the pictures. This was an easy hike and was an amazing find!
beautifull view. but easy and sometimes croudy

I hiked this trail Saturday February 10, 2018 in the morning. I started around 8 am and it took about an hour to reach the end. There was a bit of snow at the beginning but none at the end. There was a lot of icy areas hidden with a dusting of snow. No animals were sited. I saw a few fresh coyotes and rabbits tracks on the path.

I hiked this morning, December 9, 2017. 
It was great.I had the whole Trail to myself.
I heard a Coyote howling from a distance. The Gulf of St. Lawrence was so calm that the Magdelan Islands that belong to Quebec 40+ miles away were visible. 
I was able to take 20 photos of the awesome view of the landscapes and one spruce grouse. 
I did see a rabbit go by but he was too fast for my camera.
Très bien pour la partie où l'on a vue sur le cap
Well marked and so pretty. Signs at start say the yellow return section is very hard but it isn’t: following the suggested AllTrails route is fine.
Beautiful Trail. Well Marked. Perfect spot for a picnic lunch ay the top.
Had a great family hike today - good for all ages/skill levels.  Be sure to bring water - it was a hot one on a sunny day!

Walking along the rails to trails before we got to main path was so beautiful. Its such a scenic walk. And once you get to the top there is such a wonderful view of all of Chester.  Would definitely recommend
Absolutely lovely! Stunning views.

Some reviews have said it is boring. While I agree that the first 3 Kim’s is all that exciting, there are a few bridges, Barry’s Brook, Labrador Lake and a bubbling brook. 
It’s all flat, even crusher dust, old trail bed until you come to the actual Castle Rock loop. Easy to spot where but once you get to the top of Labrador Lake, it’s right there. 
There are 3 trails, but the blue trail is just a shoot off the red trail. Red trail is a much slower, easier hike on an old logging trail. Some short steep parts. Its 1.5 Kms. The yellow trail is much steeper and more like traditional hiking, although it’s only 1.2 kms. We took the red trail up and yellow down. 
The trails are well marked. The marked red trail is off kilter with the app and you’ll get a off trail warning for the last 3rd. But follow the marked trail and not the app. You have to look around for the yellow trail head when you’re on top of the mountain, but it is down to the left. 
The views on a clear day are spectacular. You can see all the way to Smeltzer Brook Bay near where you start. 
Trail head is in a small parking lot. Easy to start in the wrong direction. Go toward the road.
Nice look off.  Great spot to sit and enjoy the view.
Easy level and great view at Castle Rock in the end. I should have brought a bike for the connecting trail path. It is a bit boring before reaching the trail head.

Nice trail…could have biked the first part then did the climb (there is a bike rack at the start of the climb) but walked the whole way. Easy to follow, a bit of a climb up the rocks at the end to reach Castle Rock…we took the red trail up and yellow down. Both were fine, yellow had more brush and tree roots vs gravel. Beautiful vista at the top! Happy Canada Day!
Nice easy trail.
nice trail, lots of roots and rocks on the yellow trail. we’ll marked. beautiful view at the top! would recommend it.

Lovely walk along the Rail trail - really interesting with a river/ lakes alongside. The actual Castle Rock hike is about 3 k - very clearly marked off the Rail trail. You can take one of three paths - we did yellow up and red down. Yellow was really nice through the woods - red was pretty boring - more of an access road feel. View from the top is fantastic!

We did the trail on a very hot day,no shade until we actually got to the Castle Rock hike.I would recommend a cooler day if you mind the heat.We choose to do the difficult trail to Castle Rock and we made out just fine.It was tricky in spots but so worth it.Once at the top the view was beautiful.Will do this hike again in the Fall.
Castle rock itself was great. Most of this is a leisurely walk along the Chester trail and not so much of a hike.

If you’re feeling adventurous, this is a great spot! The trail has some brooks, rocks and small bridges. The hike is an 8.3 km loop, and the lookout is definitely worth it!
We spent another 2 km exploring!
Such a beautiful lookout! Highly recommend.

A nice way to spend a day. I did the full loop, and trail was clearly marked. 
Only real views are when you arrive at the peak, but there is still lots to enjoy along the way. I would recommend this trail.
awesome trail
Gets muddy in the woods, but the river made a nice place to clean up my very muddy Golden. Quite windy at the top. View was nice.
great hike!

Easy access. Starts on the Rails to Trails. Parking lot beside the East River wood mill or on the road.  Good markers. At the 3k mark go right to access Castle Rock. Great views. Hiked early March lots of icy patches but great nonetheless!

Love this trail but note that most of the trail is on the Rails to Trails. The trail is well marked for three levels of difficulty to scale up to the top of Castle rock. Beautiful views at the top! If you wanted to experience the hiking trail portion faster, you could mountain bike on the rails to trails and lock your bike up at the trail head. Think I will do this the next time!
Great winter hike! When you hook onto the castle rock trail from the rails to trails there are three ways you can take to get to castle rock. Signage and well marked.
Easy hike, short
Nice trail but with the ATVs it was really icy.
nice trail .the views are amazing
It was amazing, couldn’t have asked for a better day to hike up Castle Rock.
Lovely part of the Rails to trails and wonderful view on Castle Rock. So worth it!
Lovely view once you reach castle rock! The majority of the hike is on the rails to trails which is very flat and not very scenic.

Not sure if this trail is necessarily easy. The first 30 minutes to an hour are definitely easy, but once you reach the actual Castle Rock trail it can be a bit of a challenge. Majority of it is uphill and the terrain isn’t the flattest. 
Very scenic and quiet once you get uphill, though. However there are a TON of ATVs on this trail, which kind of ruin the peace and quiet of the place. Probably encountered more people on ATVs than people actually walking the trail.
The amount of ATVs also makes this trial difficult if you have dogs with you. A real shame.
good walk
Great shape. Pretty dry.

I would rate this trail as moderate. Great 3hour hiking trail. The straight path is a good warmup and cool down, the blue path and yellow path forms a nice loop with stunning view on top of the hill. I would come every fall.
Lovely trail. Well marked. Sunny and shady spots. The steel parts are steep so not for themselves with knee issues but really lovely!

lovely day. view diminished due to


 fog

Amazing hike! The trail is perfect. Took the yellow trail up and it was difficult but satisfying once you got to the top. Lots of rocks and roots to pay attention to. Beautiful sunny day so the view was amazing! So worth it!
Great trail! Went with a group of friends and we all found it equally challenging and beautiful. Great views from the top!

Not very exciting walk along the Rail Trail to the actual trail up (better for biking) but the trail thereafter was fun. As everyone has mentioned, the last bit is a scramble up but the view is lovely. A bit muddy on the yellow route when I went and I would say that some kind of hiking shoe/boot is a necessity. Lots of roots.

Muddy on parts of trail 1. We took trail 3 up and came back trail 1. Beautiful hike - but at the top you need to be slightly agile to climb the rocks. Fine for our lot, but could see others having trouble, especially if a bit older in years. The part where you’re walking on the trail is stunning. I live in the take to trails in at Margaret’s bay and couldn’t get over this part of it. Will definitely do it again.
Super messed up my recording for this trail, but took us about 2.5 hours. Great trail. Easy to find, easy to access.

Great trail! Have been wanting to do this for awhile. Stunning views, however the bugs at the top were unreal even with a breeze. I feel like I couldn’t fully enjoy. I will definitely return in the fall.
Beautiful views all along!
absolutely beautiful for sunset and an easy walk out in the dark
Great walk/hike! Takes 3.2km to get start of castle rock and then another 1.5km up the hills. Labelled well.
First time on this trail easy to find parking. Would advise running sneakers or hiking shoes. The flies were no joke even with spray and a little wind. Lots of ATVs and bikes in trail.
Great hike for the family that offers a bit of a challenge for new hikers at the halfway mark.
Take the Chester connection trail till you get to the castle rock sign. Have good foot wear to climb the rock to the top! Beautiful view at the top! I got engaged there. Can’t wait to go back again!

Did the yellow trail on a beautiful March day. Some ice in the shady areas, but easily navigated even with a 18 month old in a child carrier backpack.

Would definately recommend and I will be back in the fall!
Was a nice hike, I agree take the yellow trail. We had the summit to ourselves and only came across three other groups.
Make sure to take the yellow route one way, so worth it!

definitely a fun trail. suitable for beginners and more advanced hikers. just choose the final trail up to the Rock wisely. If you're going to take the yellow trail you're going to need good shoes and have some technical hiking ability, but the red or blue you should be able to walk up and just regular sneakers without any trouble. the 3 km into the actual ascents to the Rock are very easy gravel top and well-maintained. the views from the top or stunning and definitely worth it.

We parked near the highway at the start of the Chester connector trail. It is a well maintained gravel (stones) road. It’s not really my preference for hiking, but the scenery on both sides is pretty nice. Great views of the rivers and ponds. Once you reach the Castle Rock trail you can continue on a similar road (red route) or take the yellow route which is mainly in the woods. It is the best part of the hike in my opinion. It’s a lot of uphill, but worth it. The view from the top is pretty impressive.
We continued the hike by following the red route back out to the Chester connector trail. Again it is a loose stone road which is great for 4 wheelers and bikes but kinda boring for a hike. 
All in all, it’s a good hike. There is pretty scenery, and a great view from the top. I’ve done it a couple of times, and would do it again, but I probably won’t do the red route again. 
I think a thank you is in order to the folks who maintain this trail, it is obvious that they work hard to keep this multi use trail in such great shape and so accessible. 
Oh... don’t forget to bring bug spray.
this is a beautiful hike.  the view is breathtaking at the top. We are going back in the fall when the leaves turn.  would recommend this hike.

Most of the trail in is well maintained. Once you make it to the loop it’s much rougher. You have three options to hike in; easy, moderate or hard. We took the hard route and I’m glad I had my hiking boots for that section. Absolutely stunning views at the top! Will definitely do it again.
Amazing scenery along the trail and from the top!
Beautiful Trail...I’d recommend ice cleats now at the end of March. Making the steep hill climb easier on ice. So much beauty for you to see.
Beautiful streams and a lake along the way, then a stunning finish.
Very nice view at the end. Worth the hike!
Fun hike with breathtaking views once you reach the top of the rock.
Beautiful view.

Great trail. Though there is a long portion along the old railway (Rum Runner trail) to get to the base of Castle Rock Mtn it follows along a picturesque creek, ponds and Labrador Lake. If you cycle the rail trail part there is a bike stand to lock up your bikes before doing the Castle Rock climb.

Note the parking location is not signed on Hwy 329 and access to it is right where the trail crosses 329 and looks like you will drive down the trail on the east side. But if you use this map it will help you locate it.
great trail with an amazing view at the end.
Nice easy hike but I only gave it 3 stars because 6k of 9k are on the rails to trails. Nice view of Mahone Bay when you get to the top of Castle Rock.

Castle Rock Trails are accessed from the Chester Connection Trail.  There are currently three trails with varying degrees of difficulty and appropriate uses. Wayfinding posts are now in place and a trailhead kiosk is coming soon. There is parking in East River alongside the rail trail. Up to date information and a trail map is available from www.chester.ca.  This is a new property for the Municipality of Chester.  Your feedback is always welcome.  Enjoy everyone.  It's a lovely hike.
Gorgeous trail! Excellent for beginners, no mud at all, nice and flat. Definitely one of my favourites!
The view from Castle Rock makes it all worthwhile. I did not enjoy the long walk along the Road. In the future I would walk in and out along the old rail line.

Very easy hike - basically just walked back the tracks several kilometres (away from the ocean - closest to exit 7 but on highway 3. After a few kilometres along the flat tracks you see a little road to the right with a castle symbol on a small sign. As you go along, look for the yellow, red, or blue castle signs. Follow whichever one suits your difficulty level. None of them are overly difficult - I might recommend not taking your dog up the hardest/steepest trail and you have to walk up or down some rock face. Parts of the trails very very muddy - mud holes you had to try to get around. You scramble up the final section of castle rock. There's a Canadian flag at the top and the view of the Atlantic Ocean is beautiful. You can see for miles in all directions due to how high you are. This was an enjoyable hike and I would do it again.
Well marked and interesting trail, expect mud and challenging roots. Long stretches of beach walking on big loose rocks, ankle support a must.
New favourite! What a beautiful hike!
lovely. second time doing it. muddy in places.

Trail was great for a quick adventure. Be prepared for a little mud en route (leave the sneakers home). I prefer hikers for this trail. A few bugs but not too bad.  Poles aren't a bad idea either. Enjoy!

Beautiful and the perfect cool temperature thanks to the breeze. A bit muddy in spots. We saw two porcupines, with one of them close enough that our dog could have been quilled if she was any more curious...

I’m not sure how so many people rated this 4 or 5 stars.  The weather is what gave this review one more star.  Make sure you wear pants or your legs get scratched up due to the “trail” being so overgrown.  There are sporadic markers but several areas where you can’t be sure where you are going.  Bugs weren’t too bad for the most part but bring spray.  Also, I can’t stress enough that you wear good quality hiking boots, preferably with as much ankle support as you can - it is rare to have sure footing.  Tons of muddy areas and washed out paths, even our dogs had some difficulty.  All in all, not worth it.  There are many other trails that give better hikes with better views.
awesome trail. Has everything from Sandy beach trail to heavy brush
Beautiful hike. Tough hiking though. Lots of mud, roots and rocks, but so very much worth it!

Love this trail! Amazing views, multiple trail options, and lots to see. 

It was VERY wet. You definitely need hikers unless it’s been hot and dry for several days. There were a few sections that were nearly impassable with deep water. 

The signage is also terrible. It doesn’t look like they upkeep the trails much at all, especially the outer trail. 

Otherwise, wonderful experience!
Amazing hike, great beach. trails are a but muddy, but that's normal for early June.

Beautiful day out, not too many people on the trail. Little little buggy and muddy in places but beautiful views of the ocean and great hike. It was slightly challenging and rocky in places￼ but overall not too hard

Doing the whole loop is 7.2km not 12km as the signage in the park suggests. Trail was fine, muddy and wet is some areas. Unfortunately trail is becoming wider in spots as people try to go around the muck. Beautiful beach too.
Great trail nice and easy trail. Prob one of my favourite yet. It’s wet in places so good sturdy shoes are best. So nice as the fog rolled in.

Gorgeous trail! I just did the Spry Bay loop today. The trail is quite muddy in places so wear boots you don't mind mucking up! IMPORTANT: please try to stay on the original trail as much as possible, even if it's muddy. A lot of people are walking around the muddy areas and destroying the flora on the sides of the trail, making it an even bigger, muddier mess. It's a trail, not a road, and let's keep it that way :)! Plus, getting muddy is part of what makes hiking so fun!

This trail is challenging if it’s muddy, which was the day I went. Overall though, the trail is great. A good mix of woods and coastal walking, with great views all around. 

There’s plenty of wildlife to see, with some folks saying they see porcupines (I didn’t see any).

The park has a beautiful beach in addition to this great trail; all worth checking out!
Stunningly beautiful - magical forest - perfect day out

I loved this hike. Gorgeous coastal views.  Terrain is really varied, part woods, shore, rocks, brush - really interesting. Lots of tree roots and rocks and small ups and downs. It rained really hard the day before so parts of the trail were quite muddy and soggy. Some of the sections by the shore were insane with seaweed flies but you could pass through pretty quickly. Option to cut the trail in half if you want and only do the red loop. Took us about 2.5 hours with a decent break at the look off at the half way mark on the point. Overall I loved this hike and will definitely go back again.
Did the full loop today and it was beautiful! some parts that were washed out in the spring were much more passable   trail is well marked and was moderately busy.
Great hike, but be cautious of the wasps nest right around 44.790031, -62.544333
This is a wonderful trail, beautiful scenery. The path is well worn down, with the exception of the south side when the trail is on the rocks. Going clockwise, as suggested by others, is a good idea.
This trail is great. There is an amazing beach and the views and scenery is awesome.
beautiful scenery on both sides of each loop! there's an option to do smaller loop, or the larger loop. the beaches are are beautiful & the 2 larger ones are near parking area.

I walked this at the beginning of the summer and I think about it all the time. So stunning, special, and super biodiverse. Very wet and boggy like a coastal area should be! There’s definitely a couple of sketchy spots that are not clearly marked, but I found it easy to get back on track when I veered off. Highly recommend going for a dip at the beach when you’re done ;) 


Also! I encourage you to look up the Indigenous histories and presents of the land you’re hiking on. Think about what it means as settlers to use this unceded Mi’kmaq land for pleasure.

Well marked trail. Clearly walked and very popular. Rest area beach’s are rotted, not much of an issue. Scenic. 

Trail is lots of roots and little ups and down. Long stretches of loose beach rock to walk. Little mud but no major water holes. 

TIPS: Take poles! They helped a lot. Go right, end at the beach. Cool water on your bare feet after hiking was relaxing and refreshing. 
Suggest Norse Cove Camping, close by. Lots of amenities and hot showers. 

Happy Hiking!!
Great place to hike with lots of views of the ocean.  Trail has lots of roots and rocks so good footwear will help. Start the hike to the left side of the loop.
One of the most beautiful places you can visit on this side of the province... Stunning views and charming trail ways! cannot wait to come back and explore more of Taylor Head!

I did the Spry Bay loop yesterday which is the first part of this map and cutting across the tail in the middleish of the peninsula there. Such a nice hike even for a foggy day where views weren't much of an option. Seen lots of birds and some beautiful flowers. we stopped by the Beach before leaving too, beautiful beach!

FYI The four trails in the header are 4 separate trails totaling 21 kms, and only 2 are mapped here but the park has maps and is well marked throughout the trails.
Awesome trail. Went on a foggy day in the high teens and it was perfect. Windy at the far point, but great views of the ocean, woods, and fields. Even saw a porcupine! Highly recommend.

trail had lots of fantastic views. 

there is brush along the trail so pants is suggested. there are some muddy parts but nothing unmanageable.  

some cool birds - no idea what they were. we did see a porcupine, so if you have a dog just be wary. he was right off the trail - our dog sniffed him out. 

completed the full loop with our 8 and 6 year old, they were able to keep up fine.

One of the best trails in the province. Trail has been well maintained. Knee high brush along the way so pants recommended and some long stretches walking on beach rock. Amazing views the whole way. Relax and have a beach day when done.
Trail is well marked, in good shape and very scenic.  There are a few soggy places but nothing over the ankles.
So far I’ve only done the spry head loop but will definitely be coming back to do the headland trail. One of my favorite trails for scenery and breathtaking moments.
Great trail. Lots of rocky scenic views. Trail goes by the water and its pretty entertaining the whole route. Start to the left.

Great, mildly challenging hike. Not very people on the trail, although it was a Tuesday. Nice and scenic. Did the full loop of 7.2km’s wouldn’t recommend to kids under 10. Great for dogs that like to hike and climb.
Best coastal hiking trail in Nova Scotia! Nothing else to add!
Fun trail
March 19 2020. Great hike!  Trail is wet with snow and ice in the woods. Wet in open areas.  hiked red and yellow plus walk in and out to main road.  18k took 4 hours
A must for every hiker!
Stunning hike. Took our group of 3 around 2.5 hours to complete. Highly recommend walking out on the rocky peninsula at the start of the trail. Seals galore!

Hiked this trail last week. Beautiful views everywhere. Clean up of downed trees after Hurricane Dorion was excellent. We had a strong south wind that day. North side calm. South side extremely windy. Difficult traversing the stoney shores on the south side. Definitely would go again.
Great hike! Stayed on the north side on the red and yellow trails and good views of the water most of the time. I’d recommend if you’re in the area.

I agree with the previous poster about time estimates being conservative—we hiked just the top part of the figure 8 shape and it took about 2.5 hours. Sweet but inaccurate signs are posted along the way, telling you how far you’ve come and how far you have left to go. The path was slightly overgrown but not impassable. The views were gorgeous!

Definitely a smart move to hike clockwise. North side is more overgrown. 

Posted estimates of time are really conservative.
Sehr schöner Trail, trotz Sommer (Juli) doch teilweise sehr nass- Wanderschuhe sind hier angebracht- aber wunderschöne Aussichten , toll!
ein toller Trail durch abwechslungsreiches Gelände --- sehr schön!

We went on Dec 31. Note, the gate is closed so you walk in — it has to be at least 4km walk in — it’s a pretty road along the water but you need to build that timing, 45-1hr walk in/out into your plan. We only did 1/2 of the first loop as a result. There was some ice on parts of the path which is pretty rooty and rocky so that slowed the pace as well.
Lovely trail and amazing seaside views.. beach walk is bit confusing but nice little challenge and the app work great to keep you on track!!

Hiked this and loved it. Previous comments about path being overgrown are bang on. In fact on north side, path is almost impassable in places - so do this side first or prepare for a demoralising second half!

Hiked this and loved it. Previous comments about path being overgrown are bang on. In fact on north side, path is almost impassable in places - so do this side first or prepare for a demoralising second half!
Great views good hike busy trail
Did the Spry Bay trail. The trail was overgrown and had to be careful of ones footing. Did the hike after a rain and it was very boggy in spots. Glad I had a change of shoes

Amazing coastal views. We did the trail clockwise and it was incredible how the scenery changed around the halfway point and we weren't expecting it. Bring a sweater or a windbreaker as it is particularly windy on one side.

Fantastic hike most of it is on the coast or beach with sweeping coastal views in all directions. I would, however, recommend proceeding in the clockwise direction as the north side of the trail is poorly maintained and it’s better to start with that then end with it.

I did this trail in the summer months last year, great trail however along the coast within the rocks lived copious amounts of wharf spiders. I do not recommend hiking in the summer summer if you are fearful of them.
Taylor Head is one of my favourite places to hike. The coastal trails are always great.  The water is always cool but such a beautiful place.
Great for a rainy day. Watched the eagle where the interpretation on eagles is. Perfect view
beautiful spot

Amazing and scenic trail. perfect for walking, cycling, running etc. Recommend bringing bug spray though, I stopped to take photos at the beginning of the Salt Marsh Trail and ended up with probably 30 fly bites. I cycled from Shearwater to Lawrencetown and it was fantastic, very easy to navigate. Will be going back again

Absolutely beautiful! Well groomed, clean and easy to navigate. We should have parked in Parking area #3, but parked in #1 instead, which  was 2.5k from the start of Salt Marsh trail. Did about 12k but will be back to do the rest!
Great walk and a nice breeze today to chase away the mosquitos. Low tide on the way out, walked the beaches & had lunch at the Mcdonald House then walked back at high tide.
Awesome! Breezy n sunny! Did 10.8 km not 30 plus lol forgot to turn of tracker opps!
Lovely breeze on a hot day with a hint of smoke from western fires.
Good trail. Gravel path the entire way with lots of benches and a washroom a few km in
Gorgeous multipurpose trail with stunning views.
Great trail !
Beautiful trail with a nice wide walkway
Beautiful easy way to get to Lawrencetown Beach!
One of the best trails. Very beautiful and highly recommend.

Absolutely incredible trail, and we are so lucky to have so many awesome options in NS. 

We started at Lawrencetown Beach - big parking lot and there are washrooms so you can pee before you venture out. We were biking, and we think this is a great way to do the trail, so you can end at the beach and take whatever time you want there and enjoy it.

The trail is nice and flat. There are lots of benches and some picnic tables along the way. There are no ATVs allowed, so the trail is in great shape and you don’t get a mouth full of dust every once in a while. 

The views are just incredible - marshes, water, birds, horses, bridges, dykes, flowers, trees, and more. 

We biked to the Bisset Road trailhead and back and took our time - I had my 2yo son on the bike with me, and we stopped numerous times to explore, hydrate, and have a picnic.

We can’t wait to go back. The route we took was a perfect amount of time and exercise for a late afternoon excursion and supper picnic, and we ended at the beach for some wave watching and smelling the salty air - always good for the soul.
Beautiful trail for biking. Very flat, nice scenery of the salt marshes. Will be going back again.

Love this trail! Walk it 3-4 times a week all year long. Peaceful and an easy walk. Lots of wildlife to see... ducks and other waterfowl, eagles, porcupines, the occasional deer. Some well placed benches to pause for a picnic or just listen to the birds and brooks. Highly recommended.

Such a great place to ride a bike! It was my first bike ride in YEARS but so beautiful. The wind resistance was really tough during the open section and I felt like I was in a dream where you are running but getting nowhere LOL. I was peddling with all my might but I was slower than a toddlers’ walking speed. Much better on the way back opposite the wind :)
Open section best viewed at low tide!
Great walk...wide, flat gravel trail. No snow/ice today. Easy trek.
Great trail, flat, groomed, easy to follow, great length, some beautiful water views...beautiful beach though not easy to walk on the beach with the rocks.
Great spot
Amazing trail with lots of room for walkers and bikers. There are washroom facilities along the route. Also, benches and picnic tables to take a pit stop. What took me so long to explore this trail!
Well maintained and excellent trail.
The Salt marsh trail ￼is great. We were testing a electric bike from The eBike centre in Dartmouth NS.
Beauty day
Straight walk. Easy and amazing place
Beautiful but very windy! My husband's hat blew right off his head.

this is our favorite trail during the summer months. having water on both sides of the trail allows for a cool breeze during most of the walk. We have been lucky to see a Great Blue Harron during one visit and Eagles on another
Wonderful trail!
Great trail.
Full of mosquitos
This trail is well kept, has a rest room for visitors, and wonderful views. Best enjoyed at high tide.

loved this trail, however, I chose to ride my bike due to seeing other peoples comments and I must say I'm glad I did. I will go back for sure! the day I went it was super foggy so I'm excited to see the landscape in the sun.
Nice easy ride with road bike pulling dog trailer.
Nice easy trail for both walking and biking
Easy ride with Road Bike pulling dog trailer. Very nice.
Great spot for a solo hike/walk. Started at the trail head and went to laweencetown beach. The walk back isn't as exciting, and there are some rare birds to find!
Beautiful day and beautiful trail! Unfortunately very little shade. It is definitely more of a biking trail but still a lovely scenic trail to walk with your dogs. We will for sure be back again :)
Great place for a quick ride.
Did a nice half marathon today. Was pretty overcast, so not too busy. But still caught such lovely views, including rabbits and horses! It's nice and flat, so I had a really steady pace. Great trail!

A great trail to bike on a hot summer day thanks to the winds coming off the water. Biked out to Lawrencetown Beach, which was quite chilly, but very refreshing. The trail is a bit rutted for the first couple of kilometers, but not that bad. Lots of benches available along the trail; we stopped at one in the shade for a quick snack.
17 and overcast when i walked it. Only did about 2.5 kms in and back from bisset road. Great scenic views.  Once you get past the trees its windier so there aren’t any bugs.
Great spot for a quick run or walk.   Beautiful views.

Did this trail today in about four hours. Would definitely recommend lots of sunscreen and many layers as the open areas over the water are very cold and the inland areas get very hot! Lots of bikes!!
Great trail for road biking beginners.. quiet chilly, lots of places to rest with amazing views of sunset
Very windy. Open ocean terrain as far as the eye could see.
Great trail. So many spots to explore in one place. Very peaceful and beautiful.

awesome trail, the place is absolutely beautifull and peacefull. 

Very easy, except if there is strong wind.
Easy gravel trail that is very level and good for walking, running, biking. Beautiful views of the salt marsh. Can be breezy and cool during cooler months. Lots of different birds in the area.
Nice and easy out and back trail with beautiful scenery. You can really see how quickly the tide moves when standing on the bridges.
Love the salt marsh
Trail is beautiful to walk, run or bike. I have biked the whole thing all the way to Lawrence town beach and back and it’s breath taking. Also a very nice place to walk your dogs or run!
Cloudy day. Bugs were a bit bad but bearable.
Good day for a bike ride on Salt Marsh Trail. Dry trail and not much people at 5:00. Got a bit buggy at the end around 5:30-6:00. Good trail overall. Recommend it.

I really enjoyed this one. It was a gentle easy stroll or walk at a fast pace if you want. A lot of people so it can get busy but the views can be beautiful and places to sit if you want to have a rest. Coming back the same way isn’t as much fun but I still saw lots of birds and the sun reflecting differently on the water. It is a well maintained flat surface.
Excellent for hiking or biking. In extreme weather or hot and cold you experience the feeling of being all by yourself.

We love Salt Marsh trail especially in spring/ early summer and fall. It can be a bit too windy if the weather is windy or gets too hot in peak of hot weather. But otherwise it’s a great trail. You can see blue herons, eagles and many other interesting birds and sea creatures. It’s well maintained and has washroom in the beginning if needed. Great for hiking, biking.

Would be great for biking, though I wish I didn’t have to double back and return on the same route. Great scenery and bird watching. Loved catching the tide changing at Lawrencetown Beach which is where I parked. Very flat and manicured trail, beginner /afternoon stroll level of skill required. Very much a wheelchair accessible trail!!!!
High recommend the trail.
Only walked about 4km on this trail, but it was an easy stroll with beautiful views of the saltwater marsh. I think this trail would be most enjoyable taking a bike and covering more distance.
I did only a small portion but what I did was easy and enjoyable

Absolutely awesome. Had my six year old ride along side for 16kms and my three year old in a bike trailer all the way to Lawrencetown beach. My wife stayed with the kids while I rode back to Bissett Lake to get the car. Great day!
Great biking trail! Scenic, well-groomed. Came out at Lawrencetown Beach - fantastic spot to stop and rest and then turn around and head back. Love it!
Great views. Must do! Cycling only otherwise won’t see anything
Definitely preferred biking over walking it!

Not bad, mostly flat, decent view, good exercise. Bring water and snacks! 

We also saw 2 eagles they were huge and they went woosh woosh wee and flew away i slow motion. Prey coo

Great trail for on leash dog walking. Tons of other people around 

Kinda boring and not aloud to have dogs of leash but over all not bad.

Nice flat trail you can do a short walk or a long one depending on your mood. 
It's out and back easy to navigate with nice views
nice and easy walk
Walking, running, biking, It is hands down the best trail in all of Halifax. Beautiful scenery, friendly people, and nature. Amazing!
I didn’t take any wooded trails, but there were some.  The trail/road around the park was a beautiful easy walk.
I love it.
Walk this trail every morning, it is well maintained and well travelled. Lots of wildlife (including beavers) and butteflies.
Lovely sunny run this morning. Not many people out despite the gorgeous weather.
Lovely walk this morning. Lots of people and puppers out - made tons of new puppy-friends!
Easy walk and lots of free parking! Porta-potties throughout the path. Easily accessible for those with mobility issues too. Lots of benches and picnic tables to stop and take in the ocean views
Got approached by too many squirrels - one even ran over my foot! Squirrels out here be too bold.
Beautiful,  easy trail any time of day.
Wonderful walking trail. Nicely manicured in winter weather!
Cool but clear going. Beautiful scenery.
Poorly marked, but you can’t get seriously lost. I think
Nice day in the park, lots of folks out.
Nice trail easy

Can't go wrong with a walk in PPP. Dogs love it,but can get very busy,especially during mornings on the weekends when main trails are off leash. Lots of inner trails though should you choose less traffic.
Starting at the parking lot of The Language Centre at Saint Mary’s University this trail does a loop in Point Pleasant Park. An easy 5k when the regular trails are too wet or if it’s raining.
Mixed adherence to distancing from other walkers but pretty spacious for exploring. Lots of large rocks for children to climb. Varied plant life.
embarrassed to say I have been so close and never did many of the trails. just the main path. loved it. keeps you interested with interconnecting paths.
Great day for a walk on Remembrance Day. Took the two dogs out as well. Not buggy at all. Trails were relatively dry.
trails are maintained well and there's even an off-leash area for dogs, lots of exploring you can do on the little side trails!
Nice walking trail that takes you around to the water.  Not too much elevation change, perfect little outing while visiting Halifax!
Once again, this app is stopping.
Once again, the app is stopping.
Once again, the app is stopping.
A nice short hike right along the Halifax waterfront - great spot for an afternoon of exploring heritage buildings and Atlantic coastline.

Beautiful trails and heritage buildings. A little muddy at points but that is to be expected for this time of year.
A couple trails were marked Use At Own Risk because they are not maintained during winter but if you are able bodied they were still great for walking.

This is as close as you will get to Central Park in Halifax as it’s a beautiful park with endless trails and things to see. Can also see several old war bunkers and interpretive signs which is very interesting. There are a couple parking lots - this park is always extremely busy and really comes alive in the summer. Parts of this park are off-leash... some parts are no dogs allowed at all. Some are only on-leash - you have to watch your every move for little signs where the areas change. Are easy to miss. Beautiful views of the ocean/harbour and can even see York Redoubt and Dead Man’s Island from the park.

Excellent trail system for the whole family in the heart of the city! Plenty of parking but can be very busy. Washroom facilities located throughout the park. There's a rich military history to this park as well. Highly recommended!
It’s a good choice if u don’t want drive too far from downtown, especially suitable for daily exercise.
Great trail to walk if you need a getaway from the city within the city.
Perfect trail to use as alternative to urban hiking. Water views are very nice and historical significance to the area adds to appeal.

Beautiful location, especially in the early morning for the sunrise and seeing the cruise liners coming the Halifax port.   Dog Friendly off leash before 9am I believe.   Trails are well groomed and water view on three sides of the park.
a great spot to walk and see some historic forts, monuments etc. not overly challenging and good for running

Great park at the end of the city.  We walked from the cruise terminal, about 2K, and around the park.  Even in the pouring rain there were joggers and folks walking dogs.   Well marked paths.  I was sorry we didn't have better weather.
Walk in the park. If you go to Halifax, its a must do.
Good park for dog owners, if you are not a dog owner, it will probably feel a little too busy. you can find a lot better trails 20min outside of the city.
Often busy, however lots of trails
Watched the sunrise over the harbour. A great trail!
Good dog walking park. Many friendly dogs and large grassy areas for them to chase each other and play. My dog loses his mine every time I tell him we are going to the park!

One of the all-time favourites in Halifax! If you visit Halifax you must walk through Point Pleasant Park, and if you live in Halifax and have never walked it then shame on you!! Easy well kept trails and beautiful views of Halifax Harbour and North West Arm. Lots of parking at two different entrances to the park(one near the water the other starts into the wooded part). Great family walk anytime of the year!!
A historic staple for outdoor activity in Halifax.
Nice calm park, good for walk and sightseeing. Bicycles are allowed during weekdays, except for holidays.
This is a fun day trip with family.  Lots to see and do.
Amazing area !!  Muddy on the upper trail near the old military ruins, and rocky but more spectacular near the shoreline,imo. Great to see and hear the seals on the rocks !
Nice shoreline walk, not muddy when we went.
Wow. Absolutely stunning.  Nice breeze from the water.  Nice challenge without it being too long.
Excellent trail for a hot day. Cooling breeze coupled with great views.
A fathers day hike that was awesome.  Seals, Waves, Sun, Rocks and fantastic views
Perfect!

We decided to try the trail going along the ridge and connecting the two bunkers. The higher part is easy going but muddy. Unless you hike with people really tired from the way out, I recommend to stick with the shoreline.

Great hike. It’s pretty much the same hike as Duncan’s Cove. Before we went we thought it may have been down the way from the hike we’ve done many times before but it was the same lol. Still had a blast, stunning topography!

Vraiment très beau ! 
Mais très fréquenté, y aller tôt serai préférable.
Good but a little muddy at the beginning
Stunning views!
Great coastal hike
One of my favourite trails. Great for spotting seals! Perfect ocean walk for a hot summer day.

Great trail, a bit hard to find the proper route to take once you get to the shore line - thank god for this app(many different trails all leading to roughly the same spot). It was pretty foggy and muddy in spots but me and my pooch made it work. We also didn’t go to the very end as the fog was thick and we were both tired from all the uneven rocks. Will go back(when clear skies).
Nice views. Stopped before the end of the trail because I lost interest. Just because I haved lived here all of my life and "been there, done that"
This is a top-shelf hike close to Halifax, with many beautiful views.  I've seen seals and dolphins regularly.  It's really a great hike to bring out-of-towers to show the beautiful NS coast.

On this route there are a lot of private property signs.  Park on the one side of Gannet Ln then head down a lane way a few mins (lots of private property signs) in a bit you will see a sign that says trail and it will be on the right. Believe the hype. This place is absolutely breathtaking and worth every second of pain to get there. We are moderately experienced and average fitness, and this was a real challenge. It took 2.5 hours in, and 3 hours out. The terrain/elevation graph on here is well worth examining so you can get a sense of what lies ahead; there are many stretches that are unrelentingly steep with loose and uneven footing so knowing just how much longer you have to go on any particular stretch was a sanity-saver for me. Be aware that the trail is also one-person wide pretty much all the way, with steep hillside on one side. Tread carefully! On the outward journey, halfway in you descend into a river valley and this is a good place to rest, and refill water if you have filtration.  Things to take: hiking poles (or a good stick) are essential - trust me, you will need them. And take more water than you ever think you’ll need; my three-litre camel pack ran dry with about 40 mins return to go. And food, whether a packed lunch or a bunch of energy snacks, is a good idea. 

As for the Cove itself - absolutely STUNNING. Meadowlands, hillside, beach, forest, rocky headlands, with a river estuary splitting the beach in two. We spent 2 hours here and easily could’ve spent six more. Next time, we will definitely pack (lightly!) for an overnight. It would be magical!

The horses were the highlight. Friendly and inquisitive, we spent some time saying hi. A little later when we settled in for lunch the whole herd came running over in the hopes of food - not aggressive, at all, but a group of 1000 KG+ curious horses can be pretty intimidating! We had to move aside and watch as they trampled our stuff and ate what they could; at one point, I had to wrestle my day-pack from one of them who had it in its mouth! Fun, but be ready for them. 

The return is a killer, no bones about it. The descents on the outward route become the ascents of your return, and they can be brutal. By far the hardest part is the final return peak; that river valley I mentioned earlier? Yeah, you gotta climb out of that on your way back. It’s the last 90 minutes and after that climb the trail undulates steeply until the final descent to the trailhead. I imagine most people will be pushed hard by this part; us included!

Pack well, allow plenty of time if you think you need to take it slowly/take multiple rest breaks, and you will be rewarded with one of the best hikes in Cape Breton

My wife, my son and I are Adirondack 46ers and have hiked a lot over the years. This was one of the best and most beautiful we have done. It helps that today's weather was perfect - low 20s (Celsius), clear sky and modest humidity  - but it is more than that.  We were able to get to Pollett's Cove in 2.5 hours and it took the same time to return. We had been warned that this is an over-nighter, and it would be great to camp and explore the environs. That said, it is a wonderful and very realistic day hike for those with a bit of experience and hike with some speed. There are plenty of things to see - mountain meadows, deep gorges cut by streams and spectacular ocean vistas.  The trees, flowers and grasses are wonderful and conspire to create dramatic views to surprise at almost every turn. Then there is the wildlife. We did not see the mythic wild horses - maybe next time. We did see an abundance of pilot whales and bald eagles.  At one cove, far below us, we saw a coyote fighting with 4 bald eagles and a number of ravens over the carcass of a recently beached pilot whale. This hike has a grandeur about it and a remarkable feeling of remoteness combined with an excellent footpath. With all this said, anyone trying this hike should be prepared to work hard, exercise appropriate safety, be respectful of the environment and be properly equipped. There are very steep parts that can get slick, as well as steep drops. Beginners and many intermediate hikers will find much more accessible and appropriate trails in the Cape Breton National Park.

On Thursday and Friday we hiked Pollett’s Cove, which is in NW Cape Breton in the Aspy Fault Wilderness. The only access to the cove is via boat or the narrow trail we travelled on. It is owned by a local lottery winner who generously makes it available for public use. The hike starts near Gampo Abbey, a Buddist monastery in Pleasant Bay. The trail mostly follows the coast line and is 8km in each direstion. It starts with a very nasty climb until you reach a stretch that is briefly flat along a cliff edge. It is followed by 3 knolls and then a steep decline into the cove valley. The trail is narrow throughout, and often traverses near vertical slopes and cliffs, often rough with loose rocks. The weather was hot and muggy. I would not want to travel these sections in wet weather as it would be very treacherous. The latter part of the hike had a couple of stretches through deep wild roses and other 6 ft tall vegetation. As we were staying overnight, we carried heavy packs with our necessary gear. In total the track had 2800 ft of elevation change. Easily the most difficult we have completed so far. The cove was outstanding consisting of a valley with a mountain stream draining to the ocean and populated by at least 11 wild horses who are very tame and curious about campsites. The night we were there there were about 12 fellow hikers staying overnight, all half our age. It was fun watching the horses visiting the campsites in hopes of food rewards. Among the horses was a foal who was still nursing. While in our tent reading, some visited us as well. A beautiful place truly in the wilderness. This was our first overnight tenting hike and we had a sleepless night which made the trek out exhausting. We were awakened by coy-wolves howling on the nearby hillside. On the trail, some of our fellow hikers came across a bear cub.
We will visit here again though we will be more economical with our packs which were too heavy.
